Cut them off from the interior, and they were cramped as regarded progress, and were occupied in struggling to meet the bare cost of administration; connect them with the interior and their future would be great and far-reaching. It had been questioned why West Africa had not made more progress in the march of civilisation. In the words of Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton it was slavery that debarred them from acquiring industries; it was slavery which prevented them from exercising the virtues of foresight and prudence; it was slavery which left them nothing to care for; it was slavery that took away from them all the incentives to industrious labour, and debarred them from all the ties of social intercourse. When we remember the small percentage of people that represents owners, we had to acknowledge that these causes still opposed development. Time alone would rehabilitate the negro in his manliness. Obstacles that blocked progress were the altered relationship between owner and former slave, the independence of the latter when compared with his former grovelling position, doubt of result or use of independence secured with abolition, doubt in minds of native authorities of consequence of any action they might initiate, non-existence of free labour markets, and inter-tribal differences, jealousies and feuds. The removal of such blocks had been and was the aim of the Government, and they were gradually disappearing. In primitive countries such as within and adjoining our West African colonies, it was the duty of the Government to initiate the capabilities of the country represented by its products. The people were industrious in their own fashion, and were ready to follow examples set, and to develop industries once they learn to appreciate their value. We wanted new staples of trade and larger areas of demand for our wares. Agricultural products must long continue the most important part of the exports from tropical Africa, and the future development of Africa's commerce would depend upon the improvement in the quantity and quality of existing agricultural staples, and on the introduction of new products, which should serve as materials for manufacture and for use in industrial arts.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.64, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'And now Portugal must—must put an end to the slave-trade from her East African possessions—or if she is unable to do so must be constrained to withdraw from the scene and allow some one else to do it for her. The horrible slave-trade carried on by the Arabs up the Persian Gulf, from the East Coasts of Africa, must be swept away. Let due notice be given in those regions, that after a certain date all slave-trade will be treated as piracy, and then a few examples will close the infamous slave-trade history of the Arab dhows.

Yes, the dawn of the day of civilization, of Christian civilization, is deepening on the African horizon.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trading Troubles in Western Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'To a palaver on board his gunboat all the chiefs were recently summoned by the English Consul, who said he regretted deeply to see the state into which the country had fallen, the want of unity that existed amongst the chiefs and people, and the general lawlessness that prevailed. He said he was ready to hear any complaints and suggestions that might be made and invited the various chiefs to speak out their minds fully, frankly, and freely. Possibly, when the Consul did this, he hardly knew what was in store for him, and what a wide field he had opened up, because ever since he has been sitting *de die in diem*. Complaints and mutual recriminations have been rife, allegations have been freely preferred, and often as frankly admitted, of the most horrible crimes, and the proceedings have been a record generally of murder and villainy of every description. However, patience and an enforcement—strictly necessary when one chief brought up a dispute thirty-three years old—of the statute of limitations have at length completed the charges and counter-charges, and the Consul has at length been enabled to give his decision. He certainly showed he was in earnest on the first day of the palaver by fining each of the chiefs half a puncheon of palm oil (equivalent to £5), because their canoes made a row alongside the gunboat. He has now formed a "constitutional government," consisting of the three most powerful chiefs, whom he holds responsible for the administration of the Bonny territory; he has severely fined numerous of the offending chiefs, and has given directions, under a heavy penalty, for the payment of the debts owing by the chiefs to the traders, which in this river amount to some thousands of pounds sterling. It is to be hoped that after this the trade of this river, which has for some time past been yearly retrograding, will show signs of improvement. Formerly Bonny used to be emphatically *the* oil river, but latterly, year by year, its export of that commodity has been diminishing, whilst that of all the other rivers has been increasing. It is an extraordinary fact that, as the price of palm oil has been diminishing month by month, the produce of it has been increasing. This simply arises from the fact that the African is too lazy to work more than is absolutely necessary to obtain what he requires, or thinks he requires. Consequently, as the value obtained in kind for a puncheon of palm oil has diminished, he brings more oil to market to obtain an equivalent supply of gin, gunpowder, clothes, &c., to what he previously received, and so the very proceeding which arises in the first instance from a lowering in the price of the oil at home has a tendency to still further decrease prices by glutting the market.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SLAVERY IN CENTRAL AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 19, a paper on "Slavery in its relation to Trade in Tropical Africa" was read before the Society of Arts, by Commander V. L. Cameron, R.N., C.B. The Earl of Dundonald was in the chair.

Commander Lovett Cameron, in the course of his opening remarks, said the slave trade went on all round the continent of Africa, and commerce had gone on with it. Our trade with the West Coast of Africa had gone on since the time of the Tudors. For centuries that trade was in slaves, and its increase was slow; but after several blows had been struck at that trade—among others by the liberation of slaves in the West Indian Islands, in America, and in Cuba—instead of their being any injury done to our commerce, our trade with the West Coast of Africa increased by leaps and bounds. It was only in 1850 or shortly after that we attacked a great nest of slave dealers in Lagos, and in 1861 it was made a British colony. Up to that time there had been no trade there except in slaves; but last year the trade of Lagos amounted to £357,831 imports, and £538,980 exports. And yet only thirty-eight years ago that place was of absolutely no value to us for legitimate commerce. On the Gold Coast slavery had been practically abolished by the British Government, but yet there was a good deal still existing owing to the native customs of the people. Even if the export of slaves from Africa was prevented entirely, the internal trade in them would still be enormous.

Formerly the slave trade was subsidiary to the ivory trade, but when porters were no longer wanted for the latter, the former remained, only the men were killed and the women and children carried away. It had been said that domestic slavery must be allowed, and that was a very difficult question to settle. In his opinion, we should, as in India, abolish the legal status of slavery, but should not rout out all the households where no complaint was made. As long as domestic slavery existed there would be a market for slaves. We must have nothing to do with slavery; while the slave trade continued it was impossible for legitimate commerce to go on as it should! If the slave trade were done away with, they would find that all other trade would flourish.

In answer to questions Commander Lovett Cameron said he had avoided speaking of the Germans for diplomatic reasons.

He had a plan for the total abolition of slavery in Africa, which he hoped to explain shortly. It was, in brief, to establish a barricade across the country by the way of the lakes, and to get authority to maintain order on that line.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, on February 26, presided over a large meeting, held in Exeter Hall, when two African explorers, Commander Cameron and Captain Hore, were announced to speak.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The Arrest of King Ja Ja', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'SIR,—I note in some of the daily newspapers an announcement of the arrest of King Ja Ja, of Opobo, West Africa, by the British Consul, on account of his disregard of certain trade obligations. As matters have come to such a crisis, perhaps you will allow me to lay before your readers some details of the whole matter in dispute, by which they may be better able to judge whether such arrest was really justified by the facts.

After the famous Berlin Conference of 1884, it was arranged by the British authorities that some one should be sent out to the Oil Rivers to proclaim a Protectorate on behalf of Great Britain over the whole district; and accordingly a gentleman was sent out as Consul, who was empowered to sign a treaty with the native kings and chiefs of the various places, of which Opobo, where Ja Ja is King, was one. One of the conditions of the treaty which Ja Ja signed (Article 6) expressly prohibited strangers going to the interior markets; this condition being further substantiated by a letter from the Consul to Ja Ja; the effect and intention of this being to secure that the European agents should only obtain their goods from the interior through Ja Ja and his chiefs.

About two years ago, owing to the depression in the oil trade, some of these agents agreed among themselves that the price of the oil and other native productions should be reduced; and Ja Ja accordingly was communicated with upon the subject, and he expressed his readiness to accept their terms; but that the "topside" (a general term among the traders there, meaning commission) should be allowed to him and his chiefs, as before. This the agents would not agree to; they were willing to continue the usual topside to Ja Ja himself, but not to his chiefs. Ja Ja remonstrated with them, and pointed out that Opobo was made by himself and his chiefs. Immediately a white flag was hoisted in five of the factories, which meant that they stop all further business with the natives. One of the firms concerned refused to agree to this suspension, and continued to trade as before.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1887#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year that has just expired has witnessed the continuance and, indeed, the aggravation of that painful depression in the trade of West Africa which existed in 1886. The average prices in Europe of the more important native products have stood even lower than during the previous twelve months, while the prolonged continuance of low prices in Africa has apparently disheartened the native producer, and tended to diminish the quantity as well as the value of his out-turn. In Europe and America an improvement has, it is true, occurred in the prices of a few leading articles of commerce, but no sign of such revival extending to the products of West Africa has yet been vouchsafed; and, while it is not forbidden to hope for better things in 1888, it would be imprudent of our readers to base their calculations on any material rise in prices, or, indeed, not to make the necessary provisions for a possible—though, let us hope, improbable—further fall. While this condition of business is doubtless felt more or less even by the wealthy European merchants trading to West Africa, the most deplorable results of the depression occur in the colonial centres, such as Sierra Leone and Lagos. Great numbers of clerks and artisans, anxious for engagements as heretofore at various parts of the coast, are unable to obtain employment, or only at reduced rates of wages.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1888#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Much has lately been said, both in our own columns and in those of our contemporaries, concerning the present widespread commercial depression which is so injuriously affecting all branches of industry, both at home and abroad. For the past few years, business, to be done at all, has had to be taken at constantly decreasing rates. Take, for instance, Palm Oil, which may be considered almost the staple commodity of the West Coast. We find that the present prices, as compared with those ruling even a year ago, show a decrease which is positively alarming: *Lagos*, which at the beginning of 1885 fetched £29 per ton, now only reaches £25 10s.; *Cameroons* and *Old Calabar* show a reduction during the same period from £28 10s. to £22 5s.; *Benin* and *Bonny* the same decrease; *New Calabar* has fallen from £28 5s. to £22; *Congo* from £28 5s. to £21 15s.; and *Irregular* from £27 to £21. The chief point to be borne in mind in this connexion is that we must not look for any great improvement upon the present prices, at least to anything like the old figures. The only thing that remains is to cheapen the cost of production, so as to be able to meet the state of the market; and it would appear that the only means by which this can be effected is in the introduction of improved means of transit. We hear of the formation of a syndicate to develop a railway in the Congo Free State, by which it is hoped and expected to bring the produce of that vast district into the world's markets, and in return to supply the ever-increasing demand for European manufactures which is sure to arise when once the development of the Interior takes tangible shape. Every well-wisher of Africa must hail this project with satisfaction, but the question will arise, "Why should the West Coast settlements wait?" Here we have not a prospective, but an actual present trade, which, although at present in rather a low condition, only needs careful attention and development, and is even now capable of an almost infinite expansion. Great Britain has a paramount interest, from an economical point of view, in assisting the West Coast settlements to develop themselves. She is pre-eminently one of the greatest producing countries; more than any other, she has need of new channels for the disposal of the produce of her vast activity. Such a...', 'last_edit_date': '1886-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1886#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Produce Markets', 'section_title': '', 'content': "LIVERPOOL, FRIDAY, JUNE 8.

**SUGAR.**—Market very depressed, and only a moderate amount of business done at a further decline of 3d. per cwt.

**GINGER.**—250 bags Sierra Leone at 35s. to 36s. per cwt., as in quality.

**GUM.**—Business in Arabic Sorts is rather small at 40s. to 41s. per cwt. for ordinary quality, being steady prices.

**MYRABOLAMS.**—350 bags second Bombay on private terms.

**CAMWOOD.**—Small sales Grand Bassa at £10 10s. per ton.

A Royal Commission has been appointed to inquire into the causes of depression in trade. The causes of the depression in African trade are not far to seek, and the remedies must be applied by the Government, and not by the merchants. The apathetic policy which has been pursued, the systematic ignoring of those who have knowledge and experience, and the entrusting of important interests to incompetent hands, have had the effects which were to be expected, and unless some decisive action is taken soon, we may expect our African trade to go from bad to worse, and be all transferred from London, Liverpool, and Bristol to Hamburg, Havre, and Marseilles.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REPORT ON THE IVORY TRADE OF 1879', 'section_title': '', 'content': "**REPORT ON THE IVORY TRADE OF 1879.**

**Mincing Lane, London, 9th January, 1880.**—Of 444 tons imported in 1879, about 100 tons went to Liverpool over and above the quantity sent thence to London for sale in this market. 112 tons were brought to auction in Liverpool in the course of the year; and of the stock in importers' hands on the 1st instant, not submitted to auction, 22 tons are at Liverpool.

The deliveries from the Dock Warehouses in London in each of the last 16 years was as follows: In 1879, 402 tons; 1878, 489½ tons; 1877, 506 tons; 1876, 478½ tons; 1875, 470 tons; 1874, 514½ tons; 1873, 464 tons; 1872, 610 tons; 1871, 549 tons; 1870, 457 tons; 1869, 441 tons; 1868, 431 tons; 1867, 518 tons; 1866, 396 tons; 1865, 556 tons; 1864, 620 tons.

The striking and important fact (to which we would call special attention) brought out by the statistics for the past year, is the very great falling off in our supply of Ivory. The deficiency amounts to nearly 200 tons—about 30 per cent. compared with the receipts of 1877-78; and we must go back as far as 1855 to find a year of parallel importations. No doubt this large reduction is to be accounted for in some measure by shipments from Zanzibar to this country, which were only sent here to be transhipped to the United States, and which did not enter into our stocks; and also by direct shipments to Hambro', Holland, and France, of Ivory, which had previously found its way, directly or indirectly, at any rate to a large extent, to this market. But, after making every allowance for this, the deficiency in the total exports from Africa last year must have been very heavy. hh: Portuguese settlements on the West and East Coasts of Africa, including Mozambique, were deeply involved in the slave trade, with government actions indicating active regulation and international concerns highlighting the complex dynamics of the period.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the deep involvement of Portuguese settlements on the West and East Coasts of Africa, including Mozambique, in the slave trade. The textbook highlights the Portuguese role in the slave trade, particularly in Angola and Mozambique, where they established military outposts and agricultural estates (prazos) to facilitate the trade. Angola was a principal supplier of slaves to Brazil, while Mozambique was significant for the Indian Ocean trade. The Portuguese relied on African intermediaries and coercive labor practices, reflecting active regulation and involvement, though their control was limited, especially in Mozambique, where they depended more on Brazilian and mulatto merchants than on Portuguese officials. The African Times articles further illustrate this involvement, noting the active slave trade from Portuguese rivers north of St. Paul to Prince's Island and Mozambique's notorious reputation. They mention the capture of the powerful chief Mucuse, a principal slave exporter, and the involvement of Portuguese officials in slave trading activities, such as purchasing 1,200 slaves from the King of Dahomey for plantations in San Thomé. Both sources highlight international dynamics, such as British anti-slave trade measures and the challenges faced by British and Portuguese forces in suppressing the trade, indicating international concerns and the complex dynamics of the period. Despite claims of the Portuguese government's desire to end the slave trade, doubts about the sincerity of local authorities in African settlements persist. Together, these details provide a nuanced portrayal of Portuguese involvement, regulatory actions, and the international efforts to address the issue, reflecting the complexities and limitations of their control during this period.

[{'document_title': 'The countries of the Zambezi basin', 'section_title': 'The slave trade and incorporation into the capitalist world economy', 'content': "Ironically, those rulers and merchants engaged in the quest for additional captives occasionally became victims of the political and social upheavals generated by the slave trade. In several instances, they overstepped their authority and enslaved their own subjects or neighbours in order to main› tain the flow of wealth and weapons upon which their power rested. The Makua aristocracy pursued such a self-destructive strategy. Until the 1850s the Makua had been the principal exporters of slaves to Mozambique Island. One by-product of their predatory activities was a large-scale migration of the victimized societies. [{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'Now, Sir, you will scarcely credit it when I inform you that two of our cruisers overhauled and boarded the Zaire on her last voyage to Lisbon, bringing her to with a round shot across her bows, and on one of the occasions the boarding officer, not being apparently satisfied with Captain Beanco's papers, expressed a desire to have the hatches opened. To this indignity the captain remonstrated so firmly that the demand was withdrawn.

It is for these ill-judged acts that we are so disliked on the Continent. Here is the mail-packet of a small friendly Power forcibly detained some three hours on an important voyage because two young commanders of the Royal Navy will not use the discretion of a middy to discriminate between a slave steamer and the well-known Loando mail-boats!

It is to be hoped that the earl at the Foreign-office will check this extraordinary zeal; for, however desirable it is to obliterate the slave-trade, some care should be taken not to insult flags who "traverse the ocean on their lawful occasions."

**Africanus.**

The writer of the above, who seems to think that it may possibly be desirable to "obliterate" the slave-trade—whatever that may mean—seems not to have been at all aware that the said mail-steamers conveying the mails between St. Paul and Lisbon have only too frequently carried also slaves, under the name of "free emigrants," from St. Paul to the island of St. Thomas. The slave-trade is very active just now from the Portuguese rivers north of St. Paul, being carried on in launches between those rivers and Prince's Island, with what ultimate destination of the wretched captives our readers will be able to conjecture; and we are glad to see that our cruisers pay an occasional visit to the

mail-steamers plying between St. Paul de Loando and Lisbon. We have no doubt of the sincere desire of the Portuguese Government to put an end to the slave-trade. But we have great doubts about any such desire on the part of the authorities in the Portuguese African settlements, whether on the West or East Coast. We have very little doubt of a slave-trade being still carried on from the Portuguese settlement on the mainland near Bulama. We know, as above stated, that it is actively carried on between certain rivers and Prince's Island, and the Portuguese possessions on the East Coast, Mozambique, &c., are unhappily notorious as regards the slave-trade. The Portuguese Government know and lament all this, and are not, we think, disposed to take umbrage at our endeavours to assist them in restraining the unlawful acts of their distant officials. We care very little about the impression on the minds of the latter on occasions of such inspection as above alluded to. —Ed. A.T.

[{'document_title': 'East African Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Captain Brownrigg’s fatal encounter with a slave dhow off Pemba will give fresh interest to the despatches which are to be found in a recently published Blue Book, and which relate to the slave trade that is still actively carried on on the East Coast of Africa. Consul O’Neill, reporting from Mozambique, estimates the present export of slaves from the Mozambique coast alone at from 3,000 to 4,000 per annum. The cruisers on that coast are very active. In the four years 1876-79 they succeeded in freeing 991 slaves, and it is not their fault that they do not do more. When we glance at the area which includes slaving operations, and compare it with the number of vessels employed to check the slave trade, the difficult nature of the task is at once apparent. The total length of coast from which slaving operations are carried on may be said to be over 1,000 miles, and the sea area upon which British cruisers are employed is over 500 square miles. The work of suppressing the traffic is left in the main to England. The Portuguese are only spasmodic in their action, and difficult to move quickly when slaves are reported by our officers in their neighbourhood. They always let the news get wind, delay after delay occurs, until they arrive just in time to find the slaves gone. The Portuguese vessels of war are worn out or useless, and the French, as we shall show presently, hinder rather than assist in the suppression of the trade. As to other Great Powers, they do not profess to take part in the work, so that we have only to rely upon ourselves for all active measures. Yet the greatest number of ships we have furnished for service in these waters has hitherto been three, and they are usually the most worthless ships in the Navy. To suppose that the slave trade on the East Coast of Africa can be destroyed by means so disproportionate to the end aimed at is to credit English officers with impossibilities. We think but little of spending four or five millions, in another part of the same continent, in invading the country of a neighbour who has never wronged us; we spend double that sum without a murmur upon a fruitless march upon Coomassie; yet we cannot afford to substitute swift cruisers for worn-out hulks when the work to be done is the freeing of the slave! Nor must it be forgotten that, the more efficient the service, the greater the number of captures made, the more money goes to the Treasury from the sale of condemned ships. Even with the present inadequate force on the coast, the ships condemned involve payments to the British Navy, which, in the last four years for which we have the accounts, amounted on an average to upwards of £12,000 per annum.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE SLAVE TRADE IN EAST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "_Lisbon._—News from Mozambique states that the Governor of the province, Councillor Cunha, had ordered the transport Principe D. Carlos to visit certain points of the seaboard at which it was reported that negroes were being shipped to be sold as slaves. An English corvette, at the invitation of the Governor, sent three of its launches to accompany the Portuguese on their expedition. The expedition suffered many privations and hardships during their seven days' search along the coast. No vestiges of any traffic in slaves were met with, though the Mouros Mogojo and the negroes were completely armed and prepared for defence, which would almost imply that there was some foundation for the report that an important cargo of slaves was about to leave the coast. The Portuguese Governor-General has published a degree in reference to the expedition, in which he eulogises the conduct of the English Lieut. Stopford and Midshipmen Connop and Burnard. The Portuguese Commander of the expedition, Lieut. Metzener, likewise praises in his official report the conduct of the sailors under his orders, part of whom, landing at Mocambo, had to march a hundred kilometres under a scorching sun. There is likely, however, soon to be occasion for interference, for the missionaries are in the habit of sheltering runaways, and a collision with the man-stealers is certain to be the result.

We hear that information has been received at the Foreign Office of a satisfactory combination of armed forces of England and Portugal in the suppression of the slave-trade in the Mozambique Channel. Her Majesty's ship Vestal has sent her boats to prevent the approach of dhows to the Umpesi, while the Portuguese troops have been engaged in checking the land transport.", 'last_edit_date': '1880-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1880#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.715, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PORTUGAL AND THE WEST AFRICAN SLAVE TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It must have sounded improbable to European ears when lately there came the news that the Portuguese Government had purchased 1,200 slaves from the King of Dahomey, in order to send them to the coffee plantations of San Thomé, and that for the protection of the slave ship a Portuguese gunboat had been engaged. To those who know the nature of the trade there is nothing new or surprising in this circumstance. One sees upon the possessions of the Portuguese on the African coast many black men, both of whose ears are wanting. These are mostly slaves who, having attempted to escape by flight from the amenities of Portuguese civilization, are thus marked by their humane masters in order that they may know them again. Nine-tenths of the plantation labourers in San Thomé are slaves, the greater part of whom have been brought from San Paolo de Loando and San Salvador. From the latter place they were brought a year ago, chained together, and land route from Nokki to Mboma, and thence shipped to their destination. When, in October of last year, we were in Banana, on our way home to Europe as passengers on the Portuguese mail steamer San Thomé, we saw on board the well-known slave dealer Rosa, with some thirty black men, who wore iron rings round their necks as which were their numbers, the greater part of whom were landed at San Thomé, while seven men were left at Principé. It is written in an admirable and Christian spirit, and is indeed a very valuable addition to the public records of the horrible East African foreign slave trade. It intensifies, if such a thing were possible, the ardent desire we have always felt to get rid of the Portuguese, from the possessions held by them with great dishonour, and no national profit, on the East Coast of Africa. For although the slave trade from Quiloa and the more northern part of the coast, direct or through Zanzibar to the Persian Gulf, be, as we hope it will be, extinguished (for we do not see how Her Majesty's Government can stop short of this after what they have already done), the fiendish depopulating work will still go on in the interior, at the back of Mozambique, so long as Portugal retains her imaginary possession by "a false and iniquitous claim" to the sovereignty of a coastline of 600 miles, from Quillimane to Cape Delgado. But how is this cancelling of Portuguese claims and partial occupation to be effected? In the present temper of the English mind as regards national expenditure for Christian and philanthropic objects, it would, we expect, be useless to say, "Buy them out," even if they had really anything to sell. But they have nothing to sell, unless an exemption of that part of Africa from the sickening horrors which their presence brings with it, and in inflicting which the Portuguese people, if not the Portuguese Government, are active agents, be a thing for a so-called Christian Government to sell. It is, we think, worthy the serious consideration of Her Majesty's Government whether something tolerably effective might not be accomplished against this Portuguese slave trade by their according to the powerful Arab Chief Monsa, who seems to be the actual sovereign of those parts, that recognition which we find it stated he claims as his just right, and for which he is ready to enter into treaty with the British Government for the total suppression of the foreign slave trade. The author gives evidence of a warm sympathy with the poor African victims of the trade he was occupied in suppressing—a sympathy which gives a great charm to his book, and which we have not always found in similar works; the loathsome and degraded condition of the poor victims having too much diminished the interest that ought to have been felt in them. We are not therefore surprised to find him writing with much earnestness on the subject of the future disposal of liberated East African slaves. The disposal of them as hitherto in Bombay, Aden, &c., he looks upon, and justly, as most unsatisfactory in every respect, whether as regards the poor people themselves, the countries for which they were obtained, or our own duty towards them. He shows the necessity of not only coercing, if necessary, the Sultan of Zanzibar and all others concerned in the trade, but of forming a settlement on the mainland, from and through which civilization and industry may spread through those countries now the hunting-field of the Arab slave trader. Should such a course be adopted and vigorously pursued, we might yet live to hear of a great and happy change in those countries which will have many valuable products to send into the European markets. We have not space for his suggestions and plans, nor would it be fair to the author that we should give them in detail; they will be found in the last chapter of the work, and as it is one without which no library Slave Trade and African shelf can be complete, we recommend our readers to seek them there. We may add that the illustrations are numerous and remarkably good.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-05-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_05_1873#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.69, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN SLAVE-TRADE', 'section_title': '', 'content': "### THE AFRICAN SLAVE-TRADE.

**LISBON, Wednesday Night (July 7th).**—We informed our readers a short time since that a great blow had been struck at the slave traffic on the East Coast of Africa by the capture of the powerful chief and principal slave exporter, Mucusse. A telegram from Mozambique has just been received here, informing the Government that the relatives of Mucusse, having been advised of his capture and approaching trial, summoned their followers and attacked Sancub on June 28. She brings news from Brass, where it is feared the absence of the British Consul may lead to some serious conflicts. The steamer left on the 6th September; a few days previous to which, the natives came down the river in great force, and compelled the traders to sign an agreement not to take any of their steam launches up the Brass river. Limits were marked beyond which the launches were not to go. The British Consuls have been absent from the coast for some time, and the traders themselves sent for a gunboat to be despatched to the Brass river, in order that the difference might be adjusted, and, if possible, a serious disturbance avoided. One of the traders, who the natives alleged had gone beyond the limits, was fined by the natives. The barque Benedicta was lost on Akassa Bar on the 4th September. The crew escaped to the shore, where they were held by a native chief, and not released until a ransom had been paid for them. News from Whydah announces the annexation of that place by the Portuguese. A man-of-war went specially to Whydah, and afterwards took away, it is reported, 1,200 slaves belonging to the King of Dahomey. The slaves, it is stated, go under an agreement to work in the plantation at St. Thomé, an island on the south-west coast, belonging to the Portuguese. A recent despatch has it that the whole kingdom of Dahomey has been placed under the "protection" of Portugal!', 'last_edit_date': '1885-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SLAVERY AND THE SLAVE-TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Brazil has alone retained the curse which she inherited from her Portuguese rulers. At the present moment she possesses nearly a million and a half of slaves on her vast plantations, many of whom lead a life worse than that of beasts of burden. Brazil continued the slave-trade from the West Coast of Africa long after the treaty with England by which she was bound to abolish it, and there can be little doubt that many of the slaves now wasting their lives in the hard bondage of plantation labour have been imported since the signing of the treaty, *and are consequently held in illegal bondage*. It is pleasing to note that a strong abolition movement has lately taken place in Brazil, resulting in the freedom of many thousands of slaves.

Let us now turn to contemplate the "unhappy hunting-grounds" of the world—the boundless blood-stained territories of the "Dark Continent."

The whole of the West Coast of Africa is now nominally free from the curse of the slave-trade, though slavery still exists among all the native tribes, and in the Portuguese settlements forced labour is carried on under *indenture*, which is a form little removed from that of actual slavery. Free settlements, such as Liberia, Sierra Leone, &c., have progressed considerably under the influence of commerce and free labour, and this progression would have been much more rapid were it not for the stigma that attaches to labour in all countries where slavery has been a permanent institution. On the East Coast of Africa the great island of Madagascar has cleared itself from the reproach of the slave-trade. The importation of slaves from Africa was put an end to by the late Queen Ranavalonamanjaka II. in the year 1877. With regard to the Portuguese territories in Africa (Mozambique, &c.), it is difficult to speak with precision. The authorities declare that no slave-trade exists, but the evidence of English officials and missionaries in Eastern Africa throws considerable doubt upon that statement. Zanzibar alone of all the Arab powers on the East Coast of Africa has cleared herself from the stigma of the slave-trade. The mission of Sir. Bartle Frere in 1873 paved the way for this movement, which was completed by the recent treaty between England and the Sultan. Slavery
**111**

Still exists in Zanzibar, but, owing to the cessation of the nefarious traffic in human beings, a very marked increase in the prosperity of the people has taken place. For centuries that trade was in slaves, and its increase was slow; but after several blows had been struck at that trade—among others by the liberation of slaves in the West Indian Islands, in America, and in Cuba—instead of their being any injury done to our commerce, our trade with the West Coast of Africa increased by leaps and bounds. It was only in 1850 or shortly after that we attacked a great nest of slave dealers in Lagos, and in 1861 it was made a British colony. Up to that time there had been no trade there except in slaves; but last year the trade of Lagos amounted to £357,831 imports, and £538,980 exports. And yet only thirty-eight years ago that place was of absolutely no value to us for legitimate commerce. On the Gold Coast slavery had been practically abolished by the British Government, but yet there was a good deal still existing owing to the native customs of the people. Even if the export of slaves from Africa was prevented entirely, the internal trade in them would still be enormous.

Formerly the slave trade was subsidiary to the ivory trade, but when porters were no longer wanted for the latter, the former remained, only the men were killed and the women and children carried away. It had been said that domestic slavery must be allowed, and that was a very difficult question to settle. In his opinion, we should, as in India, abolish the legal status of slavery, but should not rout out all the households where no complaint was made. As long as domestic slavery existed there would be a market for slaves. We must have nothing to do with slavery; while the slave trade continued it was impossible for legitimate commerce to go on as it should! If the slave trade were done away with, they would find that all other trade would flourish.

In answer to questions Commander Lovett Cameron said he had avoided speaking of the Germans for diplomatic reasons.

He had a plan for the total abolition of slavery in Africa, which he hoped to explain shortly. It was, in brief, to establish a barricade across the country by the way of the lakes, and to get authority to maintain order on that line.

Lagos has for many years had a large trade carried on by British and other European merchants, yet this did not prevent it from being at the same time the head-quarters of slavery in the Bights. At Whydah an extensive trade in palm-oil has existed since 1849, and yet slaves have been regularly shipped from that port up to the present day, and, as has been already stated, a cargo was awaiting embarkation there in December last. Nor is this difficult to explain; palm-oil, which forms the principle article of trade, is collected by natives, chiefly domestic slaves, residing at or near the coast, its weight and bulk preventing it from being brought from a great distance in a country where there are no rivers; and it is evident that it would answer the chiefs better to turn their labour to account in this way than to sell them for exportation, even were not the customs of the country entirely opposed to such a proceeding. hh: The slave trade drastically depopulated and disrupted African societies, leading to the decline of once-thriving communities across the continent.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that the slave trade drastically depopulated and disrupted African societies, leading to the decline of once-thriving communities across the continent. The textbook describes how raids and slave-trading activities led to the depopulation of entire regions, such as the Ajawa raids and areas around Lake Nyasa, exacerbating rural dislocation and economic instability through the loss of productive members and recurring famines. It highlights the destruction of social and political structures due to violent slave procurement methods, including kidnapping, raiding, and wars, and notes the economic dislocation caused by undermining local industries with imported goods. The self-destructive strategies of rulers and merchants who engaged in the slave trade further led to internal fragmentation and vulnerability to external invasions. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize the severe impact of the slave trade, noting that entire regions were depopulated and transformed into deserts by slave hunters, as seen in Manyuema, once rich in ivory and population, now desolate. Testimonies from explorers like Dr. Livingstone corroborate these accounts, describing how flourishing communities were decimated, with survivors fleeing in fear. The internal slave trade also played a role in depopulating vast districts, with villages raided and inhabitants either killed or captured. The environmental impact is noted, with once-cultivated lands reverting to bush and forest due to the loss of human activity. While the textbook mentions some regions that managed to exploit the weaknesses of their neighbors to maintain relative prosperity, both sources collectively illustrate the profound social, economic, and demographic impacts of the slave trade on African societies, aligning closely with the claim.

trade, and determined to rid others of it, if possible. At every difficulty we kick and complain. Instead of swallowing the bitter pill like men, we try to spit it out like spoiled children. Look at us now! We have drifted into a little war with inaccessible barbarians. Lamentable events have occurred. Not the sword of the enemy, but sickness and death, have dogged our footsteps. Many valuable lives have been uselessly sacrificed. The cries of the suffering, the anathemas of the bereaved, have made themselves heard. And how do we meet this visitation of retributive Providence in a country that we robbed of hundreds of thousands or millions of lives by the slave-trade, which we and others carried on there for above one hundred and fifty years, at the twenty-six slave forts established by Europeans on a coast line of only two hundred and fifty miles? Let us get rid of the thing altogether, is the cry. Because it does not pay—when we have done nothing to make it pay; because it robs us of lives—when we have done nothing to remove from it those things that are fatal to life; because we have not yet got money by our repentance—we fret, and fume, and kick, and rebel, and "will have none of it." But we cannot away with it. We cannot get rid of our disagreeable responsibility. There is what the heathen termed a "Nemesis," but which we know better as Divine Retribution. We are told that, 250 years ago, those now protected territories contained a population of not less than five millions of people; that they were almost clear of bush or forest; were like a garden, and cultivated in every part. We and others set to work to depopulate them by the slave-trade carried on at those twenty-six slave forts. How well we effected it is established by the fact that, even now that the slave-trade has been discontinued there for fifty years, the total population cannot much exceed 300,000. As population disappeared, bush and forest grew up. They are created rapidly where vegetation marches with such giant strides. With such tropical bush and forest, with decayed vegetable matter poisoning every stream and watercourse, and fifty other sources of disease, a country must be fatal to civilised man. We are suffering now under those fatal influences. But again we say, we cannot therefore give up our charge; we cannot, as has been hastily suggested, give up our protectorate (unless to convert the territories into a colony); we cannot confine ourselves to certain points of the coast, and leave the remainder of the country to its fate. Our doing so would inflict lasting disgrace upon us, and we should be compelled by a cry of public indignation here to retrace our steps. For what would be the immediate result of our abandonment? The Ashantees would recommence forthwith the work of devastation, slaughter, and slave-catching, from which nothing short of our influence and power would ever have induced them to desist; and the population, except within range of the guns of our forts, would be exterminated. The Bishop of WINCHESTER seconded the motion, remarking that he believed that Great Britain was thoroughly determined to do whatever was right and within her power to put this cursed traffic down. There was much ignorance in this country as to the amount of the slave trade on the eastern coast of Africa. So far as they were able to gather, about 90,000 slaves were annually exported from the eastern coast, and each one of these cost the lives of from five to ten others, so that from 350,000 to 500,000 might be said to be yearly carried off by the man-hunters in order to supply the materials of this system of slavery. He thought, if the country were to realise the amount of this grievous evil, it would not rest without taking more active measures to remedy the evil. It was not merely the misery of those who were thus sentenced to slavery or death, but it was far more the desolation which the system carried into Africa itself—to which he referred. Dr. Livingstone, a thoroughly trustworthy witness, said that when in 1851 he first went to the shores of Lake Nyanza he found cultivation carried on to a high degree. He heard cotton mills at work on every side, and saw the flourishing products of a man's labour everywhere. But ten years after, when the slave trade had been driven, by the necessity of finding fresh victims, to the lake, all that remained was a handful of people who fled at the sight of any stranger, fearing the man-hunters. If we neglected to check this slave trade on the eastern coast, we should abandon the work which our fathers had done, and to a great extent make useless the sacrifices they made. He was convinced that the people of England were by no means ready to do that. The reports of the committees already mentioned encouraged the belief that we might do much to sweep away this great evil. Much injury has resulted from the compromise made in order to obtain concession from the Sultan of Zanzibar, and we required now a treaty which should make absolutely illegal all the export trade from the Zanzibar territory, and a further treaty to fix a time when the system of domestic slavery in Zanzibar itself should cease. It might be argued that the Sultan of Zanzibar would not agree to such arrangements, as the great part of his income was derived from the miserable wages he received for allowing this traffic. But it could be clearly shown that he would derive more from lawful trade, because Zanzibar was well fitted to be an export trade for the best products of Africa, and between 1861 and 1867 the customs at Zanzibar from legitimate traffic rose from 245,981l. to 483,693l. With respect to the payment of 8,000l., which was suggested, it was proposed that half of it should be paid out of the home revenue and half out of the Indian revenue. Thus we might obtain the assent of the Sultan of Zanzibar to a treaty which would enable us to do away with this grave abomination. No economy was so bad as spending a large sum of money, yet a sum which was just short of effecting its object. There had been recently published in Paris a pamphlet which charged the English people with want of honesty and truthfulness in their alleged desire to put down slavery. A more ridiculous idea could hardly have been put forward, but it should make us more than ever anxious to prove our sincerity and earnestness in the work of extirpating this abominable trade. He thought that the aid of France, of America, and of other great civilized Powers, should be invoked for the destruction of this traffic. "My Lord,—Since I last wrote from here I have made a successful voyage round the southern part of the Tanganyika, and have discovered its outlet in a river named the Lukuga, a little to the south of the group of islands visited by Captain Speke in 1859. I think, also, from what I have heard from the Arabs here, that the Lualabas is the Congo. My reasons for saying this are fully stated in the letter and journal I am now sending to the Royal Geographical Society, who will no doubt afford every information on the subject. One important fact (if true) mentioned by my Arab informant requires looking into. He said he met no English merchants, although he heard of them and of our men-of-war, as all the white merchants he met traded in slaves. This, if true, would point to the Spanish and Portuguese merchants on the Congo. Of the vast importance to the trading community of England of the Congo and Lualaba proving one, there is little for me to say, but I will glance over the principal articles of export. The Guinea palm extends, I believe, from the West Coast to here; india-rubber is abundant in Manyema; sem sem (from which much so-called olive oil is extracted) grows well wherever cultivated; the castor-oil plant grows almost wild; ground nuts the same; copper and gold are found in Katanga; cotton grows well, and of two or three kinds; coffee is reported to grow wild; ivory, it is well known, mostly comes from this portion of Africa; there are many sorts of fibrous substances which might be exported with advantage, and the various millets and maize grow in such abundance that they would form a profitable export; rice also grows most luxuriantly wherever cultivated. The only obstacles to a free water communication of which I know are the Yellala Falls and the rapids on the Lualaba, a short way above the Nyangwé; the Lukuga is at present obstructed with grass, but a way might easily be cut through that. In conclusion, let me add that, in my belief, this internal slave trade will continue to increase until proper means of communication are opened up, and the country brought under the influence of civilization and legitimate commerce.'}, {'id': 5725, 'article_title': 'THE ANTI-SLAVERY SOCIETY', 'full_section_title': 'THE ANTI-SLAVERY SOCIETY', 'last_edit_date': '07-31-1888', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': "Colonel LAVIGERIE, who spoke in French, said that he addressed himself to Christian England, because nowhere could he find a greater respect for human liberty. The resolution was unanimously agreed to."}, {'id': 5780, 'article_title': 'The Suppression of the African Slave Trade', 'full_section_title': 'The Suppression of the African Slave Trade', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_12_1888#article-3', 'issue_date': '03_12_1888', 'content': 'A correspondent of the *Pall Mall Gazette* has recently had an interview with Commander Cameron, R.N., the author of "Across Africa," who yearns for a return to the land of trackless deserts and unexplored lakes. He is bent upon resuming and extending the discoveries he made twelve years ago; but it is not discovery only at which he aims. His purpose is threefold—to extend our acquaintance with and influence over the tracts of country about Lakes Tanganyika and Albert Nyanza, to scotch the serpent of slavery which is devastating districts once populous and prospering, and to promote British commerce. Commander Cameron is not the man to work at haphazard. He hopes shortly to undertake a tour of the chief cities of the kingdom to engage for this scheme the approbation and support of all classes. He has spent several days in Liverpool explaining to commercial men in that seaport the nature of his plans; and there he favoured a representative with an interview:—

"Then perhaps you would give a brief outline of your project."

"It may be better first to mention what its object is." The Commander here turned up a map of Africa, and drew attention to the chain of lakes, which, commencing with Nyassa, works upwards to a somewhat ill-defined point north of the Equator. He puts his finger on several portions of the map which represented districts that when he passed through them were remarkably populous, but were now without inhabitants, the people having been either butchered in hundreds or driven away wholesale for slave purposes.

"Following that line of lakes and rivers, which extends for some 1,200 miles," continued Commander Cameron, "you see occasional intervals of land. Now, it is upon the western side of that line that the slave-dealers, speaking generally, find their happy hunting ground; and, to bring their wares to a market, they must cross either the lakes and rivers by boat or pass over the intervening stretches of land. If only a system of patrols were established to cover that 1,200 miles of water and land, a tremendous blow at the slave traffic would be struck."

"Ah, 'if,' you say, but 'there's merit in an if.' Are you not rather assuming the whole question in your 'if'?"

"No," was the Commander's reply; "I don't think so. The thing sounds bigger and more difficult than it is. I will tell you how and why. The lakes and rivers would be patrolled by boats, which would, of course, have 'beats' allotted to them. On land a line of small forts or strongholds would have to be erected, say thirty miles apart. That would be sufficient."

"But would not that leave plenty of loophole for a slave caravan to slip through?"

"I think not. You must remember a caravan would travel slowly, but news of it very fast. The patrol would know exactly where to find their game."

"And the *personnel* of the patrol?"

"Might be freed slaves and friendly natives, stiffened with a percentage of Englishmen."'}]

[{'document_title': 'THE SLAVE-TRADE IN THE VOLTA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The intelligence we publish in this present number, of the lamentable extent to which this infamous traffic is carried on within and from the protected territories of the Gold Coast, will greatly afflict and surprise our friends. That we, too, should have our Whydah so near that of the King of Dahomey, is too horrible to think of. For the sake of a few paltry hundreds a-year, this country, which is spending half-a-million annually on the naval squadron for suppressing the slave-trade, delivers over the people of an extensive region to this monster enormity. This trade, once inaugurated, was carried on by the Egyptians, Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and Europeans down to the end of the last century, when the revival of human feeling urged certain philanthropists in England to move towards the abolition of a great evil. "At the period I took charge of the Kissy Hospitals (1837) the slave-trade was in active operation, consequently great numbers of liberated Africans were constantly received into hospital. The truth began to appear, and the operations and proceedings of the would-be gentleman were made known.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-01-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-24', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.596, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'THE SUBJECT of the suppression of that nefarious Slave trade, which for more than three hundred years has been the blot upon the history of Africa, is of such paramount importance to all who recognise that "God has made of one blood all the nations of the earth," that the failure of any effort, however crude and ill-considered, which has this high mission as its object, is to be deplored; and we are therefore grieved to learn that the German "Anti-Slavery Committee" has come to an untimely end. It was hoped when founded that it would do good work in the cause of emancipation. The placing of steamers on the great lakes promised much, which, under proper auspices, might have been fulfilled. This Committee started with a capital of about £100,000; but now the cash is exhausted, and the work is not done. It is to be regretted that so much money has been thrown away upon an enterprise which has turned out so disappointing. Something, indeed, has been accomplished, but nothing on the scale intended. But it is to be feared that the proper spirit was lacking, which alone could bring such a great undertaking to a successful issue. The earlier explorers of Africa were consumed with a determination to leave the country better than they found it. But they have been followed by a different class. The adventurer has little in common with the martyr, and the German Anti-Slavery Committee appears to have been served by men of the former type. Generation after generation British philanthropists laboured for the extinction of slavery, and ultimately their ideas took possession of British thought; but Germany has not...
[SEPT. 4, 1893.]

---

had the education of England on this matter. Much of what the German Committee meditated was sound in idea, but its methods were hardly equal to its intentions. As to the future, we may hope that when the hordes of Arab slave-dealers who infest Africa are broken up, the delivery of the country can be effected; and surely the Powers of Europe, who are so greatly interested in the development of the negro race and the negro's country, are strong enough to cast out the evil spirit by which it is dominated. So long as these ruthless Arabs are permitted to enslave its people, Africa must remain much as she is at present. The prejudice against colour dies slowly, but it is dying out, even in America; and it has come to be acknowledged everywhere that the African is eminently teachable. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'As the introduction of legitimate commerce furnishes a safer and more remunerative occupation to the negro than he derives from trafficking in slaves, it will no doubt suggest itself as one cause for this banishment of slavery from the neighbourhood of the settlements, but experience shows that commerce is in itself powerless to produce this result. Lagos has for many years had a large trade carried on by British and other European merchants, yet this did not prevent it from being at the same time the head-quarters of slavery in the Bights. At Whydah an extensive trade in palm-oil has existed since 1849, and yet slaves have been regularly shipped from that port up to the present day, and, as has been already stated, a cargo was awaiting embarkation there in December last. Nor is this difficult to explain; palm-oil, which forms the principle article of trade, is collected by natives, chiefly domestic slaves, residing at or near the coast, its weight and bulk preventing it from being brought from a great distance in a country where there are no rivers; and it is evident that it would answer the chiefs better to turn their labour to account in this way than to sell them for exportation, even were not the customs of the country entirely opposed to such a proceeding. There is nothing, however, to prevent the chiefs from purchasing for export any number of the slaves captured in the hunts which are regularly undertaken for this purpose in certain parts of the interior, and so legitimate commerce and the slave-trade may be found combined in any spot on the coast to which British authority or influence does not extend.

Thus the existence of the British settlements, and of the Republic of Liberia, has served to eradicate the slave-trade from all but one spot on the 1,500 miles of coast extending from the Gambia to Quittah; and the recent acquisition of Lagos may be said to have freed almost entirely from the curse the remainder of the coast; the two exceptions being the small spot between the Gambia and Sierra Leone, the case of which has already been referred to in the report on the latter colony, and a portion of the sea coast lying between Quittah and Lagos, immediately in the rear of which are the dominions of the notorious King of Dahomey.

It is well known that, from the peculiar circumstances of his country, this monarch is indebted for his wealth and the maintenance of his authority over his people almost exclusively to the slave-trade. Whydah, the chief seaport of his dominions, is, as it has always been, the principal place of export; and advantage is also taken, when the vigilance of the cruisers renders it necessary, of the independent towns of Great Popo, Aghway, and Little Popo, situated to the westward, the inhabitants of which are only too ready to afford every facility for a trade from which they derive such profit.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.596, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SLAVERY IN CENTRAL AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 19, a paper on "Slavery in its relation to Trade in Tropical Africa" was read before the Society of Arts, by Commander V. L. Cameron, R.N., C.B. The Earl of Dundonald was in the chair.

Commander Lovett Cameron, in the course of his opening remarks, said the slave trade went on all round the continent of Africa, and commerce had gone on with it. Our trade with the West Coast of Africa had gone on since the time of the Tudors. For centuries that trade was in slaves, and its increase was slow; but after several blows had been struck at that trade—among others by the liberation of slaves in the West Indian Islands, in America, and in Cuba—instead of their being any injury done to our commerce, our trade with the West Coast of Africa increased by leaps and bounds. It was only in 1850 or shortly after that we attacked a great nest of slave dealers in Lagos, and in 1861 it was made a British colony. Up to that time there had been no trade there except in slaves; but last year the trade of Lagos amounted to £357,831 imports, and £538,980 exports. And yet only thirty-eight years ago that place was of absolutely no value to us for legitimate commerce. On the Gold Coast slavery had been practically abolished by the British Government, but yet there was a good deal still existing owing to the native customs of the people. Even if the export of slaves from Africa was prevented entirely, the internal trade in them would still be enormous.

Formerly the slave trade was subsidiary to the ivory trade, but when porters were no longer wanted for the latter, the former remained, only the men were killed and the women and children carried away. It had been said that domestic slavery must be allowed, and that was a very difficult question to settle. In his opinion, we should, as in India, abolish the legal status of slavery, but should not rout out all the households where no complaint was made. hh: The depopulation caused by the slave trade led to significant environmental changes in Africa, including the overgrowth of dense forests and the emergence of miasmas.
result: The claim that the depopulation caused by the slave trade led to significant environmental changes in Africa, such as the overgrowth of dense forests and the emergence of miasmas, is addressed differently in the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The General History of Africa textbook does not provide direct evidence supporting this claim. While it discusses the socio-economic impacts of depopulation, such as rural and economic dislocation and the disruption of agricultural activities, it does not explicitly link these to environmental changes like forest overgrowth or miasmas. The text mentions the spread of new crops and changes in agricultural practices due to external contact, but not directly as a result of depopulation. Additionally, demographic shifts and changes in food sources are noted without connecting them to environmental consequences, highlighting a gap in the textbook's coverage of the claim. In contrast, The African Times news articles offer several details supporting the claim. They describe how depopulation from the slave trade led to the rapid growth of bush and forest, as vegetation overtook previously cultivated and populated areas. This overgrowth, along with decayed vegetable matter, is said to have contributed to the creation of miasmas, posing health hazards. An article specifically mentions the Wassaw country becoming a dense forest due to depopulation, exacerbating the insalubrity of coastal districts. These observations from The African Times align with the claim by emphasizing the environmental and health impacts of the slave trade, reinforcing the perspective that it had profound ecological consequences in Africa.

These observations align with the claim by highlighting the environmental impact of the slave trade, specifically the transformation of landscapes and the health hazards that arose from these changes. The articles do not provide any information that refutes the claim, thus reinforcing the historical perspective that the slave trade had profound ecological and health-related consequences in Africa.

trade, and determined to rid others of it, if possible. At every difficulty we kick and complain. Instead of swallowing the bitter pill like men, we try to spit it out like spoiled children. Many valuable lives have been uselessly sacrificed. The cries of the suffering, the anathemas of the bereaved, have made themselves heard. And how do we meet this visitation of retributive Providence in a country that we robbed of hundreds of thousands or millions of lives by the slave-trade, which we and others carried on there for above one hundred and fifty years, at the twenty-six slave forts established by Europeans on a coast line of only two hundred and fifty miles? But we cannot away with it. We cannot get rid of our disagreeable responsibility. There is what the heathen termed a "Nemesis," but which we know better as Divine Retribution. We are told that, 250 years ago, those now protected territories contained a population of not less than five millions of people; that they were almost clear of bush or forest; were like a garden, and cultivated in every part. How well we effected it is established by the fact that, even now that the slave-trade has been discontinued there for fifty years, the total population cannot much exceed 300,000. As population disappeared, bush and forest grew up. They are created rapidly where vegetation marches with such giant strides. With such tropical bush and forest, with decayed vegetable matter poisoning every stream and watercourse, and fifty other sources of disease, a country must be fatal to civilised man. We are suffering now under those fatal influences. But again we say, we cannot therefore give up our charge; we cannot, as has been hastily suggested, give up our protectorate (unless to convert the territories into a colony); we cannot confine ourselves to certain points of the coast, and leave the remainder of the country to its fate. Abandon the coast towns of the Gold Coast, indeed! Why not say at once, "Cut off one of the fingers of the right hand of British enterprise." Many of our neighbours, and not a few among ourselves, prate of the increasing degeneracy of the present race of Englishmen, and the gradual decadence of Great Britain; and we should feel that we had cause, however reluctant we might be to admit the truth of this, if we could believe for a moment that the idea of abandonment of our West African possessions was for a moment really entertained by the British Government and people. Abandonment because there may be a certain amount of individual suffering connected with possession, and, above all, when the causes which lead to that suffering are remediable and removable, is a new word for Englishmen to hear when uttered with respect to any legitimate possession of the British Crown. We owe, moreover, a great debt, not to the present inhabitants of the coast towns of the West Coast of Africa, but to the entire countries and peoples, which we with other European nations so grievously injured by participation in that foreign slave trade which led to the depopulation of vast districts, and their consequent surrender to the encroachments and ultimate domination of that wondrous tropical fertility which covered them with their present dense and almost impenetrable forests, giving rise to the miasmas inseparable from such a condition. Abandonment is impossible. Improvement is possible, and being possible ought without delay to be inaugurated. If the work be now commenced and steadily pursued, the late events, although they have caused an expenditure that ought never to have been necessary, will not have been altogether to be deplored.'}]
