It was supposed that the Khedive aspired to rule Central Africa by improving the navigation of the Nile, and therefore he might bring an important influence to bear upon the slave-trade.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1876#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL COMPANIES FOR AFRICAN TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But it takes so long to undo evil, and destroy its baneful venom among mankind, that the infamous slave-trade, though scotched, is not yet killed. European Governments, even when sincere, are lax and feeble, fitful and vacillating in their inadequate efforts against it. It can only be thoroughly destroyed in one way. It flourished in an European and Asiatic desire for an accursed gain.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LETTERS OF DR. LIVINGSTONE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Some of your readers know that about five years ago I undertook, at the instigation of my very dear old friend, Sir Roderick Murchison, Bart., the task of examining the watershed of South Central Africa. The work had a charm for my mind, because the dividing line between North and South was unknown, and a fit object for exploration. Having a work in hand, I at first recommended another for the task, but on his declining to go without a handsome salary and something to fall back on afterwards, I agreed to go myself, and was encouraged by Sir Roderick saying, in his warm, jovial manner, 'You will be the real discoverer of the sources of the Nile.' I thought that two years would be sufficient to go from the coast inland across the head of Lake Nyassa to the watershed, wherever that might be, and after examination try to begin a benevolent mission with some tribe on the slope reach to the coast! Had I known all the time, toil, hunger, hardships, and worry involved in that precious water-parting, I might have preferred having my head shaved and a blister put on it to grappling with my good old friend's task. But having taken up the burden, I could not bear to be beaten by it. I shall tell you a little about the progress made by-and-bye. At present let me give you a glimpse of the slave trade, to which the search and discovery of most of the Nile fountains has brought me face to face. The whole traffic, whether on land or ocean, is a gross outrage of the common law of mankind. It is carried on from age to age; and, in addition to the untold evils it inflicts, it presents almost insurmountable obstacles to intercourse between the different portions of the human family. This open sore in the world is partly owing to human cupidity and partly to ignorance of the more civilised of mankind of the blight which lights chiefly on the more degraded. Piracy on the high seas was once as common as slave trading is now. But as it became thoroughly known the whole civilised world rose against it. In now trying to make the Eastern African slave trade better known to Americans, I indulge the hope that I am aiding on, though in a small degree, the good time coming yet, when slavery as well as piracy shall be chased from the world.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1872#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In 1865, the period when M. Rohlfs crossed the Fezzan, many things were related to him respecting the local administration. He was witness at that time of the following scene:—On a certain day, the doctor of the garrison presented himself at the residence of M. Rohlfs, begging him to dismiss his servant, and to close the door; he then entered upon the subject of the slave trade, and, according to his statement, there was an understanding between the authorities and the slave traders. These latter only guide their convoys by night. As soon as the caravan arrives, the corporal of the watch begins to count heads; the Kobrassi presides at the opening of the city gates, and the Kaimakan receives a report; he, as governor, demands this, because his perquisite is the sum of two mahbouds (ten francs, or about eight shillings English money) per slave; this is regarded as a small gratuity for his son-in-law, Kaivasbacha. This contraband proceeding must be very profitable, if we are to believe the good doctor. The Kaimakan had allowed at least four thousand slaves to pass through the city of Mourzouk in 1865, but the number might have amounted to ten thousand when crossed the Oasis. This information was of the greatest importance; but it is sad to be obliged to say, that in giving it, the doctor acted not from a feeling of humanity, but merely from jealousy; in this work of lucrative deception, the Kaimakan had not given a single mahboud either to the Kobrassi or to the doctor.

This, then, is the manner in which the slave trade is continued in defiance of all laws. Though the law condemns it, public opinion sees in it only a national institution which it is not forced to give up; the authorities shut their eyes, or favour a commerce that assures to them handsome revenues. As for the supervision of European Powers, it has been as nothing for many years past. The consuls confine themselves to the principal ports on the coast, where the traffickers never come; the consular agents, in the interior, are not always wisely chosen, so that their surveillance is not efficient; both parties frequently fail with respect to the knowledge necessary to render it so.

It seems established by evidence that the traffic in slaves, far from decreasing, is more flourishing than ever. An old inhabitant of Kouka declares, that during the last twenty years a greater number had been sent from Bornou than had been, previously, for one hundred years.

The merchants, whom the police of Europe disturbed in some places, no doubt, concluded that their traffic would be less interfered with beyond the solitudes of Sahara.

*(To be continued.)*', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The accusation is a solemn one. "The Sultan," M. Rohlfs informs us, "is a wholesale merchant himself. What is that in which he deals? What is it? Why, his brother man; he procures such for his own benefit by razzias over the surrounding peoples, or over his own subjects, so long as these latter have not embraced Islamism." In order to understand the abominations connected with the Eastern slave trade, we must rid ourselves of our European ideas, and enter a new world, in which men and events have in store for us more than one subject of surprise.

It is easy to form an opinion as to the importance of this slave traffic in this region, when we know the extent of the caravans that convey the negroes from Kouka. During many weeks, the preparations and the departure fill the capital with noise and bustle. Long files of camels are laden with provisions, two thousand armed men serve as an escort, and the human flock altogether counts four thousand heads. For the Sultan, for his horsemen, for his wholesale merchants, for the entire city, the caravan season is a great annual festivity; for the slave, it is the moment of banishment, the renewal of sufferings, and perhaps the eve of his death. Very speedily all this multitude has taken a northern direction, and soon it disappears from the side of the desert.

But this crowd of unhappy beings, these miserable creatures of all ages—children, young men, old men and women—where are they going? What agricultural or industrial labour demands them from the Eastern coast? What route will they take, since the north of Africa, the borders of the Mediterranean, belong to those Powers which proscribe the traffic? It is on account of these apparent difficulties, and because of the mysteries in which the Oriental trade has been involved, that it has been able to conceal itself, until the present day, from the observation of Europe.

We refrain, for the moment, from replying to the first of these inquiries. We shall learn later what becomes of these unfortunates.

We are about to see how these flocks of men, in spite of their number, can, without hindrance or denouncement, cross those countries in which the slave trade is prohibited.

Between Tripoli and Kouka lies the Oasis of the Fezzan, in which the Porte holds a garrison of five hundred men, commanded by a Kobrassi.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sometimes the wind causes the mouths of the wells to be filled with sand. When this is the case, some of the negroes, not having sufficient strength to wait until the needed clearance is made, die; and their companions have barely the strength to remove the corpses.

The traveller whose name we have before mentioned, relates that he met with a certain spring surrounded with what might emphatically be called a field of the dead: there bones were laid about in heaps. His servants, who had drawn water from this spring, without observing it, carried off in the bucket the skull of a man. These human skeletons, mingled as they are with the bones of the lower animals, are the remains of slaves.

On leaving these frightful solitudes, where man is proved to be more merciless than the desert, reaching the zone of the forests, the eye is rejoiced at the sight of rich vegetation, flowers and lakes, these latter giving to the soil an endless source of fertility.

But in the midst of Nature, which God has made so rich, sorrowful reflections come over the mind. This privileged land is the theatre of slavery, and the home of the man-hunter. The large city of Kouka, in the vicinity of Lake Tchad, the capital of Bornou, is one of the greatest marts for this human merchandise.

On the Square, the best adapted for the slave-markets, one is sure every day to find several hundreds; but on Monday, the great sale day, they may be numbered by thousands; the blacks are there exhibited in their pitiable plight, partially covered with miserable tatters. The wholesale merchants and connoisseurs have no need to be attracted by a more delicate exposition, such as that which one would meet with in a retail purchase.

The slave is examined with care, taking measure of his height, opening his mouth, counting his teeth, asking questions about his appetite, &c., &c. The price demanded is according to his age, strength and colour of the prisoner, and varies from half a sovereign to five pounds for the current merchandise. Is this all that a man is worth, and is this the estimate put on human liberty? There are other markets at which the slave is considered of still less value.

But whence come all these wretched beings? It is here that the Eastern traffic is presented to us under a particular aspect, such as it did not assume on the western coasts of Africa in the organised commerce of slaves. Man-hunting, which supplies the victims for these markets, is not only encouraged by the brutal ferocity of the chief of a tribe; it is considered an act commanded by religion.

The Sultan, who goes to make razzias at the head of warriors, with whom he divides the booty, by an impious aberration believes that he performs a pious work in spreading devastation around him. This is the effect of the old Mahomedan influence, and the sword of the knights follows the infidel enemies of the Koran.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BADAGRY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The traffic in slaves is still carried on between Porto-Novo, this place, and Whydah. This inflicts very great injury on the legitimate trader, as the slave-dealers make sacrifices on the sale and purchase of goods and produce, in order to drive the English traders out of the market. Their profit on slaves compensates them largely for the loss they thus sustain in driving away the enemies of that traffic.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**THE SLAVE TRADE IN AFRICA IN 1872.**

*CHAPTER I.*

*CENTRAL AFRICA.*

In the first step we take in the examination of this great subject, we find in the train of the man-hunters horrors which were unknown to the former slave trade.

When the negro was brought to the coasts of Guinea, to be sold to the American purchasers, he had not to make long days' marches across the dreadful solitudes of Sahara. In the new traffic, organised for the markets of the East, the black that has just been severed from his family and deprived of his liberty, while suffering unheard-of cruelties, must traverse the vast plains of sand which separate the interior of Africa from the borders of the Mediterranean, in order to arrive at the place of his future servile existence.

The desert, with its scorching sands, devoid of verdure and springs, with its storm-driven dust that buries caravans, seems more terrible than the ocean, and to cross it requires a more lengthened period.

From the town of Tripoli to the Lake Tchad, there are nearly twenty degrees—an extent of land more than twice and a half the length of Great Britain. It is by this route that the convoys of negroes are driven by their pitiless masters, condemned, under the burning sun, to the tortures of thirst, hunger and fatigue. It is a long funeral march in the midst of the solitude of the desert.

From time to time one of the miserable company falls, to rise no more; his fellow-prisoners make no halt to cover his body even with a little sand. Let it not be supposed that this is a picture of the imagination only. Monsieur Rohlfs, who was an eyewitness of these things during his explorings between the years 1865 and 1867, and who was the first to denounce these mysteries of crime, gives them to us in frightful detail:—

"On both sides of the road," he says, "we see the blanched bones of the victimised slaves—skeletons still covered by the haikoun, the clothing of the blacks. The traveller who knows nothing of the road to Bourno, has only to follow these scattered remains, and he will not be misguided."

The merchants take a singular precaution, lest the slave should rob them of a few drops of water: they place the leathern bottle in such a position, that the orifice is turned towards the head of the camel that carries it. The animal, which is itself athirst, begins to cry as soon as the precious vessel is touched, and thus the attempt to partake of its contents would be discovered. Thus thirst, as well as bodily fatigue, has innumerable victims.

* "The Slave Trade in Africa in 1872. Principally carried on for the supply of Turkey, Egypt, Persia, and Zanzibar." By Etienne Felix Berlioux, Professor of History in the Lyceum of Lyon. From the French, with a Preface by Joseph Cooper. London: Edward Marsh, 12, Bishopsgate-street Without. 1872.

When evening draws on, the miserable groups often have not physical strength to drag their wearied bodies to the springs that might slack their parched mouths.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PARLIAMENTARY PAPERS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The natives of the interior are known to be eager for trade; but, unfortunately, the traffic in slaves is the principal means of paying for the small supplies of European goods which now reach them. The rivers Niger and Chadda, by means of steamers, can be made for legitimate commerce, and the produce in exchange would be chiefly Shea butter and cotton. The former is a valuable oil, and would be a new article of commerce, only a few tons having as yet been imported, while the cotton would be from an entirely new source of supply. Ivory would be attracted by the new markets when established; but this would merely be a diversion of trade, whereas the Shea butter and cotton would be a new trade created.

It is obvious that time will be required to develop this trade; the natives must, first of all, feel assured of a demand for such produce when raised, and time must elapse before they are accustomed to resort to the new markets for European goods in exchange for their produce. To effect this these markets must be kept constantly supplied.

The steamers necessary for these operations will cost upwards of 30,000l., and the outlay will not be much less than 40,000l. by the time they are placed on the Niger. The cost of coals and high wages, owing to the climate, render it very expensive to maintain steamers on the river, while there are no means of repair in case of accident to the hull or machinery. Mr. Laird's steamer Day Spring was lost in 1857, and he found it afterwards impossible to insure against the risk of the loss on river surface.

While, therefore, it is necessary to commence operations by a heavy outlay in steamers, together with a great expense and risk in maintaining them, it will take several years to develop a remunerative trade, which is the reason why I have stated in a former letter, that whoever undertakes the "Niger enterprise" must be prepared to face a yearly loss for some time.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-05-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Incidents of the Slave-trade in Egypt', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A correspondent of the *Ohio State Journal* writes from Alexandria, Egypt, an interesting account of the slave-trade in Cairo, from which we take the following:—

"The trade in white slaves is in the hands of Turks, and of that my guide professed very little knowledge, but with the trade in blacks he was quite familiar. They are now seldom brought in large companies to Cairo, but they are brought so from the Soodan and Osiout and other places up the river. From these points, from one to five at a time are brought to Cairo on grain boats and other vessels. If any questions are asked, the captains, with a little backsheesh to confirm their story, can easily pass so small a number of supernumeraries as wives, children, servants, or sailors. From Boolak, the port of Cairo, these slaves are retailed, as there may be opportunity, to persons who want their services. If the vessel must move before such opportunity occurs, they are sold to a dealer, who buys cheaper than the retail purchasers. My friend told me that he had a number of black slaves, but said he had allowed them to marry, and had given them free papers, that their service with him was voluntary, and in the event of his death they would be safe from the claims of heirs and creditors. It is common for Egyptians, who know that almost all Christendom opposes the institution, to make such apologies to frank acquaintances, but in this case I believe the statement was correct.

"This conversation increased my curiosity and strengthened my determination to see the Cairo slave-pen if possible. To accomplish my purpose I made application to another native friend. He said, 'No, I am too well known, but I will lend you my coat, and you will pass as a Levantine, and there is a young man here can show you. That coat of yours looks too English.' We exchanged coats. The young man and I mounted donkeys, and in ten minutes we had left the Frank quarter and were winding our way through the narrow, crooked, and dirty streets of a thoroughly Arab neighbourhood. Suddenly my companion called a halt, and said one of the buildings we had just passed was sometimes used for a pen, and he would inquire if they had a stock at present. He came to me in a minute, and told me that if the dealer pressed any one of his women on me, I must object that they were too old; that my wife wanted a girl young enough to be trained to take intelligent care of the children. This was his plan for us to get away without revealing the real nature of our business.', 'last_edit_date': '1870-03-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1870#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The persistence and resurgence of slavery and human trafficking in colonial Lagos, despite efforts to mitigate its impacts, highlight the deep entrenchment and economic incentives that sustained these practices.
result: The persistence and resurgence of slavery and human trafficking in colonial Lagos, despite efforts to mitigate their impacts, are underscored by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook provides a broader regional context, highlighting the economic incentives that sustained these practices during the transition from the slave trade to 'legitimate' trade. It notes that regions like Dahomey continued slave trading as long as there were customers, reflecting the deep entrenchment of these practices and the role of European economic interests in maintaining a presence in Africa. However, it does not specifically address colonial Lagos, indicating a gap in detailed examination of this locale. In contrast, The African Times articles offer substantial evidence specific to Lagos, illustrating the continued slave-trade activities in the area and surrounding regions like Porto Novo and Whydah. The articles emphasize the financial motivations, with traders profiting from the slave trade and using slaves as payment for debts, and highlight the complicity and inaction of local authorities in enforcing British anti-slavery laws. They also describe societal acceptance and normalization of slavery, even among educated and Christian natives, which aligns with the claim that economic and social structures in Lagos were deeply intertwined with slavery. Despite some efforts by individuals and authorities to combat slavery, the articles depict a complex interplay between resistance and complicity, corroborating the claim by illustrating the persistence of slavery due to entrenched economic incentives and societal norms.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several insights that align with the claim regarding the persistence and resurgence of slavery and human trafficking in colonial Lagos. The text highlights the economic incentives that sustained these practices, particularly in the context of the transition from the slave trade to 'legitimate' trade. It notes that despite the abolition of the slave trade, regions like Dahomey continued to engage in slave trading as long as there were customers, indicating the deep entrenchment of these practices. Furthermore, the text discusses the role of European economic interests in maintaining a presence in Africa, which indirectly supported the continuation of slavery and human trafficking. However, the textbook does not specifically mention colonial Lagos in this context, which is a notable difference. Instead, it provides a broader overview of the economic and social dynamics in West Africa, including the adaptive capacity of indigenous societies to transition to new forms of trade. This suggests that while the claim about Lagos is plausible within the broader regional context, the textbook does not provide direct evidence specific to Lagos, highlighting a gap in the detailed examination of this particular locale.
tat: The African Times news articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that slavery and human trafficking persisted and resurged in colonial Lagos despite efforts to mitigate their impacts. The articles highlight the deep entrenchment of these practices, as seen in the continued slave-trade activities in Lagos and surrounding areas, such as Porto Novo and Whydah. The economic incentives are evident, with traders profiting from the slave trade and using slaves as payment for debts, which underscores the financial motivations sustaining these practices. The articles also mention the complicity and inaction of local authorities, who failed to enforce British laws against slavery effectively, allowing the trade to continue. Furthermore, the articles describe the societal acceptance and normalization of slavery, with even educated and Christian natives tolerating and participating in these practices. This aligns with the claim that the economic and social structures in Lagos were deeply intertwined with slavery, making its eradication challenging. However, the articles also note efforts by some individuals and authorities to combat slavery, indicating a complex interplay between resistance and complicity. Overall, the articles corroborate the claim by illustrating the persistence of slavery due to entrenched economic incentives and societal norms.

[{'document_title': 'States and peoples of the Niger Bend and the Volta', 'section_title': 'Socio-economic tensions > Production and trade', 'content': "The abolition of the slave trade by Britain in 1807 introduced an element of structural imbalance into this situation, especially in the south, where surveillance was instituted earliest and maintained most strictly, although domestic slavery was tolerated.$^{48}$ During the second half of the nineteenth century slavery expanded very substantially, especially in the Niger bend. This was because the cost of weapons increased steadily, so that pro› gressively greater numbers of slaves had to be offered in exchange. It is not surprising, then, to find entire groups, such as the Zamberma, spe› cializing in the extraction of this 'black ore'. The main sources of supply, however, were not only the great djihäd conducted by the Muslim leaders of the north and the conflicts in Mossi territory. The trade was also fed from a host of channels that sluiced off slaves from peoples belonging to hundreds of chieftaincies, from the territories of the Tuareg to the areas bordering the trading posts on the coast. During the final decades of the nineteenth century, war broke out in virtually every decade and in virtually every region, and war meant captives. These victims were for the most part from sedentary agricultural communities, which served as a veritable breeding stock for the trade. Hence the underpopulated areas to be found in regions that were literally drained of their inhabitants. Tribute exacted in the form of captives was extremely heavy in many instances. When indigenous peoples took action to organize their own defence, they were frequently used as mercenaries in wars elsewhere, as in the case of some of the Gurunsi who fought in the ranks of the Zamberma, and the Samo (Sanan) who took part in the dynastic wars of Yatenga.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'Socio-economic change and institutional adaptation', 'content': "The new changes resulted from a combination of factors, including the nineteenth-century wars which, as in Yorubaland, had the effect of ren› dering the coastal areas relatively safe and attractive to migration from the hinterlands in which most of the fighting took place; the sea-borne trade which was rendered permanent by the transition from slave to 'legitimate' trade, thereby conferring a definite economic advantage on the coastal regions; and the steady growth of European interest, which enlarged the traditional role of selected coastal towns such as Lagos, Porto Novo and eventually Cotonou to take on new and increasing responsibilities not only as ports but also as political capitals of emergent colonial states and their independent African successors.
In all these changes, however, the economic factor would appear to have been the most dominant, especially with reference to the European presence. Trade, above all, brought the European to Africa and has remained the most important consideration for his continued stay. The nineteenth century was especially critical because of the change in the established pattern brought about by the abolition of the export trade in slaves, which had dominated transactions for over three centuries. Known in European records of the pre-abolition era as 'the Slave Coast', this area of West Africa was among those most involved in the slave trade; and the relatively smooth transition to 'legitimate' trade must ultimately be credited to the adaptive capacity of the indigenous societies.
In this regard, there is, perhaps, no better illustration than the case of Dahomey, traditionally considered to be the most persistent slave-raiding and slave-trading state in West Africa. [{'id': 458, 'article_title': "Hussey's Charity (Slave Fund)", 'full_section_title': "Hussey's Charity (Slave Fund)", 'last_edit_date': '09-23-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-22', 'issue_date': '23_09_1864', 'content': "The local trustees at St. Helena shall apply the proportion of the net income so to be remitted to them, after payment of any necessary and proper expenses, and having regard to any general rules and regulations to be prescribed by the trustees, in the establishment and maintenance, at one or more places in St.

**Sept. 23, 1864.**

---

Helena, of schools for the education of Africans, or by giving aid to such schools as are already existing in the island, or partly by each mode, as the local trustees shall think fit.

The trustees shall out of the St. Helena Fund remit the sum of 1,500l. in cash to the local trustees at St. Helena, to be applied by them in erecting buildings for any such schools, and the same local trustees may invest that portion of the said sum of 1,500l. which is not wanted for such erection, on such security as they may deem best in St. Helena, and the money invested, and the interest thereof, shall be applied in repairing the said buildings, or in erecting and repairing other buildings for any such schools. And the interest not wanted for such purposes shall be invested in like manner and accumulated.

The local trustees at Lagos shall apply the proportion of the net income so to be remitted to them, after payment of any necessary and proper expenses, and having regard to any general rules and regulations to be prescribed by the trustees, in the redemption from slavery of such slaves as shall escape from the tribes surrounding Lagos to the latter place, and as the local trustees shall, after inquiry into the circumstances of each case, consider to be deserving objects of charity.

If in the judgment of the trustees it shall seem that the application of the interest of the Lagos Fund, or any part thereof, at Lagos had ceased to be of advantage, they shall submit proposals to the court for applying such interest, or a part thereof, at St. Helena, for the purposes aforesaid, or elsewhere, and shall serve Her Majesty's Attorney-General with notice of their having done so."}, {'id': 3242, 'article_title': 'Lagos Slave Buyers', 'full_section_title': 'Lagos Slave Buyers', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1876#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_11_1876', 'content': 'Moral Upas-tree of slavery overshadows all Africa. Turn where one will, one finds it poisoning the moral atmosphere, making all that is good to be impossible, spreading violence, murder, disease, misery, destruction, and death everywhere. We thought we had got rid of it within the British settlement of Lagos; but, alas! it seems to be beyond doubt that the abomination is still there. The letter of "Otitor Koro" in our last number—a letter not anonymous, but offering every guarantee of being dependable and true in what it asserts—calls us anew to the combat. We did not wait until now to respond to the call. When we first read that letter our spirit was mightily stirred within us, and we wrote immediately such a leader for our October number as the grossness of the evil seemed imperatively to demand from us. That leader, with most of the new and important matter intended for our October number, miscarried in the post—a mishap that was not known until there was then no longer time for remedy. But there is time now for us to expose and attack this abomination. The accursed thing is there, like to the forbidden spoil secreted in the tents of Achan; and there is no possibility of good for or in Lagos until it be brought forth and destroyed. Out with it, out of the tent, or hut, or house, and bring it to public light. Can it be any longer a matter of wonder that we should have had to lament that Lagos has done hitherto so much less than we had fondly hoped and believed it would do in the spread of civilization and Christianity around it, seeing that it is in itself so deeply polluted? If the source be bitter, the waters flowing from it cannot be sweet. The source must be purified. We thought this had been done, so far at least as regards slavery and slave-dealing, when Lagos was declared a British settlement, and a general registration was made of all within its borders who had up to that time been held and possessed as slaves. Shame, shame on those who now stir up within us former memories and recall to our mind the past of Lagos, when the accursed foreign slave-ships were there loading with cargoes of human misery for the plantations of Cuba and Brazil! Shame, shame, ten thousand times shame, that it is not now the greedy foreign pirates who are stimulating the equally horrid greed of the debased heathen Africans of the interior to obtain by war and kidnapping, with their attendant murders, burnings, and desolations, the hundreds and thousands of their wretched fellow-countrymen and countrywomen that were wanted to cram the fetid hold of the slave-ship! It is now people calling themselves civilized Africans, educated Africans, men and women who have been taught in missionary schools, men and women who are possibly attending divine service in churches and chapels, that are violating the most precious precepts of Him on whom they profess to believe for salvation. These, these, alas! are the people who are now stimulating the greed of the interior heathen and inciting them to the perpetration of the old enormities by becoming purchasers of the human merchandise they bring for sale to the markets of Ejirin and Ikorodu. In one respect we are not sorry that our intended leader of last month did not make its appearance in our columns. The letter on the "Woes of Ijesha," &c., which has since reached us, and which we now publish, shows us whence those poor human victims of brutality and lust are derived. Writing of the oppressed and devastated districts of Ijesha the writer, under the signature of "Okanlogue," states that the barbarous oppressors "look upon the remnant of the people in the country as their fortune, for there is not an Ejirin or Ikorodu market in which the sons and daughters of the soil are not to be found as one of the articles for speculation; besides which, many of them are daily purchased by the cruel King of Dahomey, to be offered in sacrifice at his Customs." It may be that on reading this extract some of the despicable offenders who are renewing the slave-trade at Lagos, violating the public law as well as the precepts of the religion they profess, will say, Is it not better that we should purchase these people than that they should be sold to Dahomey? No; it is not better. Their motive in buying these victims has not been to save them from the tender mercies of Dahomey, but one of lust or greed. There is not even a shadow of good in the thing; it is hideous and abominable in its every aspect—filthy and loathsome throughout. Away with it; it must and will poison everything around it. There are good men and women in Lagos,—what have they been about to allow this abomination to exist among them? There are British authorities in Lagos, and British laws are in force there,—what have those authorities been about not to enforce those laws? Lagos is not so large a place that those slave-trade practices could be carried on in a corner unknown of by the innocent portion of the community. The sole object in view by the British Government when it annexed Lagos was to extirpate the slave-trade and slavery therein and within the sphere of its influence. The foreign slave-trade is now, thanks be to God, quite a thing of the past in West Africa. There are not any slave-ships now carrying cargoes of human victims to over-sea countries. It cannot be permitted that a new traffic in slaves should be established in Lagos (for those who buy will sell also when lust is satisfied, or money may be made by it) soiling and dishonouring anew the British flag, in defiance of British law and the feelings of the British Government and people, who have done all they could to wipe out the iniquity of their forefathers, who permitted and took part in the loathsome foreign slave-trade. We call upon the British authorities in Lagos to set to work at once and put an end, root and branch, to the slave-trade and slave-holding iniquity that "Otitor Koro" has brought under our notice, and which cannot now be any further ignored or winked at. There surely cannot be an ineradicable sympathy with these practices in Lagos; but we must say it seems strange that it should have been found necessary to invoke our aid against them. Be this as it may, our duty was clear. Not only do we denounce it in our columns—not only do we cry shame upon the perpetrators of the evil, and demand immediate action against it on the part of the responsible British authorities in Lagos, but we have brought the hated matter directly under the notice of the Earl of Carnarvon, who will, we are well assured, not lose any time in expressing his disapprobation as regards the official remissness which has rendered it possible for him to be thus appealed to; and his expectation that although the new stain cannot be removed, the pollution will, at least, be effectually destroyed.'}, {'id': 3293, 'article_title': 'The New Route to Abomey, the Capital of Dahomey', 'full_section_title': 'The New Route to Abomey, the Capital of Dahomey', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1877#article-19', 'issue_date': '01_01_1877', 'content': '### TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Lagos, November 16, 1876.

Sir,—I am moved by patriotic feeling to support the true and godly statements in the columns of the October number of your journal by one Mr. "Otitor Koro"—viz., "The extensive Slave-trade Practi.es in Lagos." God bless Mr. "Otitor Koro!" May he long live to be an ornament to this community, and a blessing to his country! I hope he will not fail to furnish you with accounts of the efficacious result of his letter since the arrival of your paper containing it at this settlement. The Governor was woke up by it from his deep sleep, and changed the language of his Canute-like courtiers—viz., "Tis now my look-out" to "look sharp." It terrified Mr. Taiwo, his favorite native trader of Bishop-street, who took the precaution to lock up all his slaves in the house at the rumour of the "woeful tale;" and, to my regret, _also to the Christians!_

On the morning of the 6th instant, about thirty slaves were captured in canoes coming from Epe, Ikorodu, and Ejirin markets, by the "knickerbockered police;" and, before the afternoon, double the above number were found in the possession of resident traders and merchants. The slaves were marched up to the Government House; the Governor having consulted his courtiers and adviser, ordered their names to be recorded, and _delivered them back to their respective owners._ Not a word of warning was said to these owners for buying slaves privately. Considering this place to be a thorough British settlement, I was perfectly astounded at this impolitic act of his. This cruel practice had been long carried on in this settlement. Traders and merchants are in the habit of receiving slaves as payment from their debtors, and have them privately shipped to Porto Novo and Oke Odon for sale. Would you not, as a father to us poor Africans, see that the Home Government check this ungodly practice and also wake our authorities from their deadly sleep?

Dear Sir, what you can do in this case everybody knows; and the slave-dealers themselves are, so to say, on the tenter-hooks of impatience to know what the "Iway Illu Obba" (the English book—i.e., the newspaper of England, the _African Times_) will say about this decision. But they are also disgracefully aware that during the interval they are safe to import, export, and do what they like with their slaves, in doing which, my blood curdles in my veins to say, they are warranted by the unheard-of-in-the-annals-of-this-place indecision, and the un-English inhumanity of the _ipse dixit_ novices in the Ward-of-Admiralty-_pro-slavery_-Government House.'}, {'id': 3356, 'article_title': 'Slavery and Slave-trade in Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Slavery and Slave-trade in Lagos', 'last_edit_date': '06-10-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1877#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_08_1877', 'content': 'Sir,—I want to see slavery abolished all over the world. I hate the very name and detest the thing under every form, and I hope that so long as God spares my life I shall lift up my voice against this heinous, flagrant, atrocious, and flagitious crime. I feel that I am laid under obligation to lift up my voice against it, and denounce it as an enormous evil in the sight of God, and as one of the greatest evils of which men can be guilty to their fellow-men.

It is with considerable reluctance that I now write of slavery in Lagos, because I fear that what I am about to state may not agree with the views of many in the community here. I should be glad, if possible, not to offend the feelings or even the prejudices of any man; but the cause of truth requires, not merely that we should endeavour to live peaceably with all men, but also speak the words of truth, whether they are pleasant or disagreeable. It is, indeed, a fact that our worthy Governor Lees has been trying to extirpate the "extensive slave-trade practices in Lagos," and has done, and is also doing, all what "Oitor Koro" represents him as doing in the columns of your last month's issue; but we are sorry to say that no better plan has yet been adopted to stop domestic slavery among the community here.

Holding a "palaver" at the Government House, telling the "native merchants and traders that it is a very disgraceful thing in subjects of Great Britain," threatening them that, "whether the slaves were bought ten years ago or yesterday," the "offenders" will be brought to a signal punishment, and ordering "a few policemen to proclaim about the town that no canoes from or to any of the markets are to land or leave after sunset,"...

---

**SELLING INTO SLAVERY.**  
*To the Editor of the African Times.*  
Little Popo, May 28, 1877.

Sir,—Please insert the following statements showing that the slave-trade is now being carried on between this place and Cape Coast:—

**Statement of a Girl who has been sold in December, 1876.**'}, {'id': 4918, 'article_title': 'The Wholesale Murders in Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'The Wholesale Murders in Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1884#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_09_1884', 'content': 'In our last number, under the heading of "Lagos News," we mentioned that one Adeoshun had been arrested, charged with the murder, under most revolting circumstances, of many of the women residents of the town. Since then, further details have come to hand, and we learn that this Adeoshun has for some time been regarded as a "Ju Ju medicine man," and had acquired great influence over the females of Lagos, owing to his dealings in "charms" and "fetish." When the last advices left Lagos, Adeoshun was undergoing a police examination, and so great was the excitement in the place, and particularly among the female portion of the inhabitants, that a force of Houssas had to be specially in attendance at the police-court to protect the accused from the violence of the mob, which numbered some 3,000 people. The first charge against Adeoshun is that of the murder of Mrs. Selina Cole. This lady disappeared very mysteriously some time since, and it was thought that she had been decoyed outside the protectorate and sold into slavery—a circumstance which is stated in the despatch to be not of very unfrequent occurrence. Subsequently the husband of the missing woman became aware that certain property which belonged to his wife was in the possession of Adeoshun. A search warrant being obtained, goods to the value of some £160 were found on the premises of the accused, all of which were said to belong to Mrs. Cole. The matter having been taken up by Inspector Willoughby, of the Houssa police, a bush near the town was searched, resulting in the discovery of four skeletons, and subsequently eight more. The remains of Mrs. Cole were among the number. It is said that the accused, by the aid of his charms, was believed by the females of the colony to be able to bring them wealth. From Mrs. Cole alone we learn that Adeoshun obtained some £500 prior to her disappearance. It is stated that the prisoner induced his victims to meet him in a lonely part of Ikoyi (near where the bodies were found) and there forced them to kneel down with their eyes blindfolded. A live fowl was then put in each hand of the victims, and while in this position it is believed they were despatched by the aid of some heavy weapon. The object of the murderer was no doubt robbery, and the murder of his victims came as an after-thought, in order to prevent detection and subsequent punishment.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Extensive Slave Trade Practices in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Emboldened by the lethargic indifference of the Government, the heedlessness of the knickerbockered police force (who may in the long run join the chorus themselves), and the sheepish unconcern of those who ought to bring such parties to punishment, instead of finding 100 answers to his Excellency's query (non-official of course) of "Where lies the root of Captain Glover's fame, &c.?" emboldened by all these, I say, the more daring of the traders are in the habit of passing their own "stock" to Porto Novo and the creeks; and when nothing is done to check these nefarious traders, there is no knowing how far the practice will go. There are very few of the traders, and those not very well to-do, who have not already got a slave or two in their houses! And this in a British settlement! Can any one of your Lagos readers say No to these facts? Who is it that walks through Taji, Idumagbo, Obun Eko, Ebute Ero, Olowogbowo, and such like places, and does not say, "It is too true?"

Dear Mr. Editor, Lagos is retrogressing, we are sorry to see, into her former position before this much-talked-of cession; and unless you help us, through God's assistance, to check this downward progress, by throwing your influence into the scale, and by opening the eyes of our authorities, who can guarantee that she will not become a second edition of the old slave mart of the coast? And, lastly, when our traders with impunity import slaves from the markets, the interior warlike tribes are incited to depopulate towns and villages to meet this demand!

"Write and tell out this woeful tale;  
Record this dire eclipse."

With respects and due apologies, I am, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.633, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Covert Slavery and Slave-Trade at Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If the statements made in the following letter, which we extract from the *Lagos Times*, be correct, the covert slavery and slave-trade therein mentioned ought to be vigilantly and relentlessly pursued by the local British authorities. We hope these statements will come under the notice of the Home Government, and that the Colonial Office will call upon that of Lagos to do its duty in the matter, which is one of too great gravity to be trifled with. After the crusade we headed against these enormities a few years ago, we had hoped that Lagos had been purified of these abominations, which are a disgrace to the island, and especially to the large number of educated natives who call themselves Christians, as it is clear that if these latter exerted themselves as they ought to do, such evil practices could not continue to exist. We must confess we do not believe in the professed Christianity which tolerates and connives at what it might so easily eradicate if it were sincere:—

"Sir,—It will, I think, surprise you to know that pawning of human beings, one's own children and other relatives or slaves registered as aliens, to effect loans of money, is practised in a place like Lagos, where, in consequence of its being a portion of the British Empire, slavery and the slave-trade in any and every form are entirely and absolutely forbidden; but it is a fact that this ancient abomination and curse exists still. A sharp look-out has only to be kept to find out those who deal in it.

"No money interest is paid upon the loan contracted, but the personal labour of the unfortunate pawn till the time the loan is repaid, which is always left open and may be one year or five years, counts for interest. The pawn receives not a fraction of payment for his toils. Should he die before payment of the loan is made, or should he desert his master, a substitute is to be provided. This wicked slavery is practised under the eye of
**45**

British law, and that sometimes by persons calling themselves Christians.

"It is sometimes the case that unwary people are decoyed from this place to be sold into slavery in the neighbouring non-British countries. Not many weeks ago, a heathen woman was thus decoyed to Igbesa, where she would have been sold to the King had she not found some of her relatives there to whom she appealed for help, and protested she had never been a slave to him who would sell her.

"Slaves bought in and brought from countries beyond British borders and registered as aliens here have sometimes been decoyed out of Lagos by those who have registered them as their distant relatives and connections or other friends, and sold off again, as the case may be, and there are never wanting those who would help such persons in their wicked transactions.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-02-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1882#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE LAGOS SLAVE-TRADERS', 'section_title': '', 'content': "When, after repeated warnings, men incorrigibly persist in breaking the law, every one must admit that the punishment with which they may be visited on conviction is richly deserved. It is now twelve months since we first denounced to the authorities in Her Majesty's settlement of Lagos the large amount of slave-trading that was being carried on without let or hindrance on their part. The very first motion of the Lagos Executive, stimulated by the letters and leaders in the African Times, gave such ample confirmatory evidence of the truth of our statements, that the fact of a gross, systematic, and extensive violation of the British laws against slave-trading was placed beyond dispute. Owing, perhaps, to the consciousness that there had been a long and culpable neglect on their part, the early action of the Executive in the matter, after obtaining the above-mentioned evidence, was limited to official public warnings that all future infractions of the law would be severely dealt with. The public warnings were so given that it was not possible for any of the inhabitants of Lagos to be ignorant of them. Nevertheless, it soon became our painful duty to record that the abominable slave-trade practices had not ceased. This was intolerable; and we are now glad to make known the fact that the law has been vindicated by the conviction and punishment of some of the offenders. It will be seen in our Lagos letter that five of these slave-traders—all natives of Lagos and its vicinity—have been convicted and sentenced by Mr. Justice Woodcock, each to seven years of penal servitude. We can have no pleasure in the humiliation and sufferings of any one, even of slave-traders—we had rather see the laws obeyed, than see people punished for infraction of them; but it was quite evident that only severe measures would put a stop to the iniquitous and, we suppose, profitable traffic, by greedy men, in the lives and liberties of their fellow-creatures. The richly-deserved punishment has overtaken some of them; and we can only express the hope that this salutary example may have so deterrent an effect as to put an end altogether to what has been a great disgrace to Lagos, and prevent the necessity of inflicting further punishments. Be this as it may, slave-trade practices must be rooted out of Lagos. We said this twelve months ago—we repeat it now. We have watchful eyes about Lagos; and if we find that even these examples now made have not sufficed, we shall not fail to call upon the Lagos Executive to take further and even more extreme measures to effect the desired object. Let all Lagos slave-traders, therefore, beware.", 'last_edit_date': '1877-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1877#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BADAGRY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The traffic in slaves is still carried on between Porto-Novo, this place, and Whydah. This inflicts very great injury on the legitimate trader, as the slave-dealers make sacrifices on the sale and purchase of goods and produce, in order to drive the English traders out of the market. Their profit on slaves compensates them largely for the loss they thus sustain in driving away the enemies of that traffic.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.633, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Extensive Slave Trade Practices in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'traders who go to meet their Jebu customers in these markets, bringing home such produce as they promise to bring in return for the goods supplied them by European and Native merchants; in the first instance, slaves are brought to these markets together with some produce; and in the second, the Lagos traders receive and bring both home, keeping the slaves for their household drudgery, since they know that the merchants do not want them; and forwarding the produce after being duly adulterated to the merchants, who sometimes find the same to be bad and refuse it, and at others through much pressure of business overlook the adulteration and suspect nothing more till they are informed of the quality of their produce being too bad for the Liverpool or some other market. What is the consequence? The merchants lose, of course; and, seeing that the traders do not pay for the goods they had received, refuse to supply them with more goods; and the traders having bought slaves with the proceeds of the goods they had already received and finding they have no more ready money to pay their debts, have their houses sold, and "flee the country" before their creditors can have them imprisoned in the "hulk," i.e., the debtors' prison. Can this be regarded as conducive to the welfare of the Settlement? Who does not see and recognize these slaves in our streets? What Government officer can honestly and conscientiously say that he does not see these slaves? Can any clerk, messenger, &c., in the "Service," from those in the Treasury, the Customs, the Courts, and other officers, say that they have no reason to believe that slaves are regularly imported into the Settlement at the return from every market? Can the Superintendent of Police, whose business it is to report suchlike cases, &c., say that he does not know the difference in the dialect, aspect, &c., of these imported strangers and of those who had long been residing in Lagos? Is the Prothonotary busy about every other thing, blind to this evil? Don't all these personages see this evil, wink at it, pass on the other side like the Levite of old, and mentally add, "Tis not my look-out?"', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Extensive Slave Trade Practices in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Having waited with much impatience in the hope that some one of your many friends here would, through the medium of the African Times and your own instrumentality, expose some grave evils which our authorities overlook, and which are consequently increasing more and more; and, being disappointed, I humbly beg to be excused in asking your indulgence and wonted perseverance whilst I make this attempt at an exposure of one of them. Since 1872, a year which has been proverbial for all but what is good and prosperous for this Settlement as well as for its inhabitants, the demon of slavery, which it was thought at and after the cession had received its death-blow, has been gradually recovering, and is now, I am sorry to say, in almost its wonted strength, but very much disguised; to wit—prior to the year in question, although the interior countries were one amphitheatre of war, yet the captives taken at the wars hardly found their way here except as fugitives from their masters; but now the case is altered—instead of legitimate produce being brought to the Ejinrin and the Tkorodu markets, and instead of the Lagos', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.666, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Covert Slavery and Slave-Trade at Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are glad to see that Mr. Labouchere called the attention of the House of Commons to this important subject on the night of Friday, April 28. He moved the following: "That, in the opinion of this House, it is improper for any British official to lend his sanction to, or to aid directly or indirectly in, retaining any person in or consigning any person to slavery." And in the course of his observations he said, with reference to Lagos and the Gold Coast: "After the assumption of sovereignty on the Gold Coast, a proclamation was issued putting an end to what was called debt slavery; but he was credibly informed that no such proclamation was issued in Lagos, and that at the present moment there was a considerable amount of this debt slavery existing within that colony." Mr. Labouchere was evidently not aware of all that has been done, from time to time, against these abominations in Lagos, and of our, at the time, successful crusade against them, and thus laid himself open in some degree to the criticism of Mr. Courtney, who dilated on the "remarkable character" of the charges made by Mr. Labouchere, "who had said that he was credibly informed that slavery existed at Lagos, but who had not adduced a single fact in support of his accusation. As far as the Government were aware, slavery had ceased for some years to exist, not only in Lagos, but in the protected States, and attempts to revive it had been checked, and their authors punished." This statement of Mr. Courtney, correct as it is in the main, only serves to show that the Government have not been so fully informed of what takes place in Lagos as was the author of a letter published in our last number, signed "Libertas," and extracted by us from the Lagos Times. We recommend that letter to the attention of Her Majesty's Government, in the hope and belief that they will instruct the Lagos Government to leave no possible means unemployed to extirpate that foul thing in Lagos. We said in our last that we hoped these statements would come under the notice of the Home Government, "and that the Colonial Office will call upon that of Lagos to do its duty in the matter, which is one of too great gravity to be trifled with. After the crusade we headed against these enormities a few years ago, we had hoped that Lagos had been purified of these abominations, which are a disgrace to the island, and especially to the large number of educated natives who call themselves Christians, as it is clear that if these latter exerted themselves as they ought to do, such evil practices could not continue to exist. We must confess we do not believe in the professed Christianity which tolerates and connives at what it might so easily eradicate if sincere." hh: European involvement significantly escalated the African slave trade, contradicting the notion of it being purely indigenous and persisting despite efforts to combat it.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that European involvement significantly escalated the African slave trade, contradicting the notion of it being purely indigenous and persisting despite efforts to combat it. The textbook highlights that the slave trade was integral to the construction of a European-centered capitalist world-economy, with European merchants intensifying the trade by demanding open markets and paying retainers in slaves. This expansion was closely linked to European plantation economies, and European trading influence rapidly spread, often outpacing missionary efforts. Despite Britain's abolition of the slave trade, economic pressures and the dependency of slave-trading states on European weapons and markets allowed the trade to persist. In East Africa, European pressures for abolition were met with continued trading activities. The African Times articles further emphasize that Europeans, particularly the British, did not merely encounter an existing foreign slave trade but initiated and exacerbated it. They note that European ships initially resorted to kidnapping due to the absence of slaves for sale, indicating that the foreign slave trade was introduced and expanded by Europeans. The articles also highlight the significant population reduction on the Gold Coast due to the slave trade, with millions of Africans shipped to colonies like Jamaica. Despite efforts to combat the trade in the 19th century, European nations failed to adequately address the issue, allowing it to persist. However, the articles acknowledge the existence of domestic slavery and other abominations in Africa prior to European involvement, suggesting that while the foreign slave trade was not purely indigenous, some local forms of slavery did exist. Together, these sources provide a nuanced view that underscores European escalation of the slave trade while recognizing pre-existing local practices.

[{'id': 566, 'article_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'full_section_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': 'We join issue further with Lord Stanley on the question of debt and duty to Africa. He says that we owe none; we say that we owe both—that we owe them not only as Christians, but as Britons. The Christian claim his lordship coolly dismisses; he cannot, or he will not, understand or admit it. It is not, therefore, the less mighty and real; but we will pass it by, and come to the national one. Do we, as a nation, owe anything to Africa? Lord Stanley says we might have been under this delusion thirty years ago, but that we are wiser now, and not to be so gulled. The slave-trade was not created by England, or by any Europeans, he says; England found and used it, and no doubt aggravated the evil; but sixty years have passed since we made any money in that way, and therefore, whatever debt was owing to the people of Africa on this score, had certainly been by this time paid off." The statute of limitations, we presume—a creditable plea, no doubt, for a so-called Christian people! But Lord Stanley had not studied his facts. We did not _find_ in Africa that _foreign slave-trade_ which has wrought such incalculable evil in Africa. We found domestic slavery and abominations innumerable, but no foreign slave-trade. When European ships first went down the West Coast in search of slaves, they found it.

difficult to obtain any. There were none offering for sale. The shipmasters were obliged to have recourse to kidnapping—pan-yaring those who came off to their ships to trade in produce. But the Europeans got possession of points on the Coast—they built forts—they tempted with articles and goods that were greedily sought after. Slaves, slaves, slaves, was their great demand. We have no space here to trace the progress and tell the horrors of the new foreign slave-trade thus inaugurated. But, as has been already stated, we and other Europeans reduced the population of those very Gold Coast territories, now so Pharisaically complained of, from five millions to about two hundred thousand, having ourselves shipped from thence—only from that Gold Coast to one—a single one of our West India islands, Jamaica, above 950,000 slaves within a period of one hundred and ten years, in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; while millions were shipped during the same period from other parts of the doomed coast to other colonies. And this, Lord Stanley says, has been amply atoned for, if there really was anything to be atoned for, by a sixty-years' discontinuance of the infamous practice! For all efforts on our part to suppress the slave-trade, Lord Stanley treats as a work of supererogation. It has been, he says, a waste of money and of valuable lives, some one of which latter was more valuable than the whole existence of our African colonies. We have reduced that horrid slave export trade from Africa from two or three hundred thousand victims a-year to perhaps five or ten thousand (from the West Coast); but all this was not worth one of the lives expended in the work!'}, {'id': 2383, 'article_title': 'The Slave Trade in Africa in 1872', 'full_section_title': 'The Slave Trade in Africa in 1872', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-24', 'issue_date': '30_01_1873', 'content': 'The revelations which we receive from the borders of the Nile are still more strange, more sorrowful.

Two circumstances add a mournful interest to the spectacle which the slave trade presents to us in this its second stage. Here the man-hunters are no longer savages in whose uncivilized condition may be pleaded some extension of their crimes: Many among them are Europeans belonging to nations the most refined.

These men, the more learned, therefore the more to be dreaded, come with resources with which civilization has furnished them, to preside over a moral devastation.

We shall see more of this devastation somewhat later. In the desert, we have seen the victims dying with fatigue, the skeletons of those to whom the agony of thirst with the burning sands had proved fatal; but our information is not yet complete. We have not been present at the hunt itself; we have not seen the hunters at work; we have not heard the sound of the musketry, the cries of the fugitives; we have not beheld villages on fire, the dying writhing in agony, and the more infuriated prisoners fastened by their first galling fetters.

We may well wonder that these horrors of the Oriental slave-trade have been so long hidden from the view of Christian nations, but we find in the revelations which now reach us from all quarters, at one and the same time, an extraordinary coincidence.

At the moment in which M. Rholfs informs us of the traffic of Sahara, man-hunting is made known to us by several other travellers—Messrs. Baker, Speke, Henglin, Lejean, and the Mesdames Tinné. In their united testimony we have much important information.

He was not quite sure that the fact of a member of the Society of Friends presiding over a meeting graced by the presence of Cardinal Lavigerie, Bishops, Archbishops, and most distinguished clergy and laymen, representing different politics and religious persuasions, did not accentuate the fact that there were things on which they differed. But they all agreed that slavery and the slave trade were contrary to the laws of natural and revealed religion, and hateful in the sight of that God who watched over all of us. They had been summoned there that afternoon to hear what the Cardinal had to tell them with regard to slavery in Africa. He did not believe that his Eminence would inculcate upon them the abstract iniquity of slavery and the slave trade, for in that case he would be preaching to converts. It was true that some time ago we, by the introduction of European energy, by opening the lucrative and large markets, gave a stimulus to the slave trade which had existed for time immemorial in Africa; but, during a hundred years, we had done something to wipe off the reproach. He thought that his Eminence would speak to them of the increase of the slave trade in the centre and the East of Africa, confirming the information which we had received from our explorers, our missionaries, and from Her Majesty's Consuls. He thought and hoped he (the Cardinal) would give them his views as to the best means of combating this evil. They would agree with him in thinking that it would be absurd for Englishmen, who had got possession of the most favoured spots in the uncivilized world, that we should be jealous of any other European nation desiring to increase their opportunities of promoting civilization. Belgium, France, Germany had lately been pursuing that policy, and as a consequence we were in possession of greater rights and of greater responsibilities, and the nations he had just mentioned would feel with us the weight of that responsibility. In 1815, at the Congress at Vienna, there was a strong condemnation of the slave trade. In 1822, at a Conference at Verona, the Duke of Wellington endeavoured to have the slave trade declared piracy. At the Congress of Berlin our Plenipotentiaries found it impossible to bring forward the question at all. He was not sure that at this moment there was any obstacle to these nations coming together, and trying to arrive at the most judicious method for the purpose of putting an end to, or greatly diminishing, the horrors which he was afraid even exceeded the former Trans-oceanic traffic. The noble Earl concluded by calling upon Cardinal Lavigerie to address the meeting."}]

European Governments, even when sincere, are lax and feeble, fitful and vacillating in their inadequate efforts against it. It can only be thoroughly destroyed in one way. It flourished in an European and Asiatic desire for an accursed gain.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Cooper—now the Nestor of the anti-slavery cause—renders an immense service to it by this, his last contribution to its literature. Apart from his extensive experience as an active worker with the earliest champions of negro emancipation, his intimate knowledge of the movement, his ceaseless vigilance, and the minute attention he has given to the latest developments of the East African slave trade entitle him to address the public with authority upon this momentous subject, and we venture to hope an adequate response may be made to his earnest appeal to the British Government to make a vigorous effort to annihilate the iniquity of slavery, as the main source of the slave trade. The writer very forcibly demonstrates that even the best-intentioned measures against the traffic in slaves must fail so long as its great provocative, slavery, exists. Sir Bartle Frere and other equally distinguished modern advocates of the abolition of the slave trade, have been driven by their own experience to advance the same view; and the chief purpose of Mr. Cooper's book is to submit—which we think he does conclusively—that, were our Government to take up the question in earnest, the task of inducing Mohammedan Powers to abolish slavery would prove less difficult than is alleged.

"The principal countries on behalf of which the present African slave trade is carried on are Turkey, Egypt, Persia, Tunis, Morocco, and Madagascar. On them the responsibility for the present state of Africa now mainly rests. The rulers of these countries have in nearly every instance, at one time or other, condemned both slavery and the slave trade, and have entered into treaty engagements for the suppression of the slave-markets throughout their dominions. How is it, then, that the slave trade is still carried on in those countries, in violation both of law and treaty engagements? One answer to this will probably be found in the fact that the European Powers, though solemnly pledged to bring the system to a definitive end, have taken little interest in the subject for the last thirty years, during which period the traffic has pretty steadily increased."', 'last_edit_date': '1875-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.615, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Mediterranean Negro Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our readers will not fail to have noticed the following paragraph immediately following our leaders in the last number of this Journal:—"THE SLAVE TRADE. Constantinople, November 9.—An English steamer arrived here on Wednesday from Malta with twenty slaves on board. The traffic in slaves between Tripoli and Constantinople, via Malta, is very brisk." Few, we believe, will have been prepared for such an announcement as this. Yet, although it appeared in all our daily papers, we have not seen any other notice taken in them of the alleged facts—any condemnation of Turkey—any censure of ourselves. We have been holding public meetings in condemnation of the East African Slave Trade, the British Government has been sending out a special envoy to Zanzibar, and is understood to be adopting efficacious measures for putting an end to the traffic from Africa to Persia and Arabia—all highly commendable, and our most obvious duty—but yet here we have the Slave Trade, the foreign African Slave Trade, carried on under our very eyes—carried on where we can intercept and destroy it forthwith, if we so choose, without any extraordinary effort on our part to do so being required,—here we have it, duly exposed as an item of news in the columns of all the London daily papers, without its having elicited any justly indignant comments, provoked any addresses to Her Majesty's Government, or even, so far as we can learn (not having been ourself present), given rise to a single remark at the Baroness Burdett Coutts' evening reunion, where a Wilberforce, the Bishop of Winchester, presided over the Anti-Slave Trade Conversazione. We should have imagined that, if any item of Slave Trade news could possibly excite attention and rouse indignation, it would be such an item as this. For what does this Mediterranean Slave Trade from Tripoli to Constantinople, in steamer via Malta, mean? Where do these poor wretches thus conveyed to their final destination, come from? Alas! they have previously formed part of one of those caravans of slaves which traverse the Great Desert, from Bornou, in Central Africa, to Tripoli, the whole route of which through that Desert is clearly marked by the bleached bones of innumerable human victims of that accursed trade, carried on in Central as in Eastern Africa by Mahomedans for the supply of Mahometan countries. We have been too long accustomed to hear that this Central African Slave Trade from Bornou to Tripoli (the intense horrors of which have been often exposed, and are again exposed in the little work by Mons. Berlioz, which we are reproducing in our columns) cannot be reached by any effort of the British Government. This assertion has been invariably denied by us. It has been well known that the final destination, the profitable market, for perhaps the greater portion of the survivors of those horrible caravans, was in Turkey; and that, in some way or other, they were constantly being conveyed to Smyrna and Constantinople. Is it not, therefore, evident that a little energy and honest determination on the part of the British Government would suffice to break this final link in the chain of the traffic; and that without any very great sacrifices being necessary to effect it? There cannot be any reasonable doubt on this point; and there being no room for any such doubt, makes us to be clearly criminal participators in all the worst barbarities and horrors of that Central African Slave Trade, which we profess so vehemently to deplore and to condemn. Why are we so? Why is this, at least, nominally Christian country thus allowed to be dragged in the year 1873 through the gory mire of that accursed trade, which insults God and outrages humanity.
