It is there that the large societies of the traffickers are organized. There they find bankers who lend them money at an interest as high as cent. per cent.; the dockyards of the city prepare for them fleets of vessels to re-ascend the valley of the Nile; the neighbouring populations, accustomed to live by plunder, furnish them with horsemen and foot soldiers; some master scoundrel is placed at the head of these bands; they collect provisions for a year or more. When all is in readiness, on a fine day, the wind blowing from the North, the whole expedition suddenly disappears in a southern direction. No one can tell what is about to be done. Should any more inquisitive traveller wish to know what will become of these men; let him beware. They would begin by alarming him as to the difficulties of the voyage—the morasses, fevers, ferocious animals, and negroes still more terrible. If he persist in his inquiries, they give him to understand that there is connected with these solitudes some frightful mystery which he must not know, and that death awaits the individual who is bold enough to despise counsel. They say in explanation of the expedition that the armed men are appointed to hunt elephants, and to protect the enterprise against the attacks of the enterprising trader. These latter, not contented with the exchange of their small articles of merchandise for ivory, desire to obtain the monopoly of so lucrative a commerce for themselves. Indeed, every year large cargoes of ivory are sent to Khartoum. Slaves have not appeared there since Turkey prohibited the importation of the negroes fifteen years ago. Secret correspondents come to conduct them beyond the city by the desert to their destination, of which, of course, they know nothing. It is by these means, that the enormities of the slave trade have been concealed, as with an impenetrable veil.

The following circumstance, however, furnishes some important information on the subject:—

The death of a Frenchman was one day announced, who had been at the head of a considerable establishment, and was everywhere known as a merchant in horses, and in elephants' teeth; he wished in life to be regarded as a gentleman.

He had, by dint of labour, reached the high position of his ancestors; but what did his books, which had been kept with scrupulous exactness, disclose?

He had traded not only in ivory and horses, but in slaves. The supplies, the mysterious correspondence, the number of livery servants, all were there indicated with a precision very unfortunate for the reputation of the deceased. Their profit on slaves compensates them largely for the loss they thus sustain in driving away the enemies of that traffic.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.599, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PARLIAMENTARY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Lord STRATHEDEN (the consistent enemy of the abominable slave trade in East Africa) moved an address to Her Majesty, praying that such measures as were necessary to assist the cruisers employed in the repression of the slave trade on the eastern coast of Africa might be adopted.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1872#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.587, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Extensive Slave Trade Practices in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'traders who go to meet their Jebu customers in these markets, bringing home such produce as they promise to bring in return for the goods supplied them by European and Native merchants; in the first instance, slaves are brought to these markets together with some produce; and in the second, the Lagos traders receive and bring both home, keeping the slaves for their household drudgery, since they know that the merchants do not want them; and forwarding the produce after being duly adulterated to the merchants, who sometimes find the same to be bad and refuse it, and at others through much pressure of business overlook the adulteration and suspect nothing more till they are informed of the quality of their produce being too bad for the Liverpool or some other market. What is the consequence? The merchants lose, of course; and, seeing that the traders do not pay for the goods they had received, refuse to supply them with more goods; and the traders having bought slaves with the proceeds of the goods they had already received and finding they have no more ready money to pay their debts, have their houses sold, and "flee the country" before their creditors can have them imprisoned in the "hulk," i.e., the debtors' prison. Can this be regarded as conducive to the welfare of the Settlement? Who does not see and recognize these slaves in our streets? What Government officer can honestly and conscientiously say that he does not see these slaves? Can any clerk, messenger, &c., in the "Service," from those in the Treasury, the Customs, the Courts, and other officers, say that they have no reason to believe that slaves are regularly imported into the Settlement at the return from every market? Can the Superintendent of Police, whose business it is to report suchlike cases, &c., say that he does not know the difference in the dialect, aspect, &c., of these imported strangers and of those who had long been residing in Lagos? Is the Prothonotary busy about every other thing, blind to this evil? We hear that information has been received at the Foreign Office of a satisfactory combination of armed forces of England and Portugal in the suppression of the slave-trade in the Mozambique Channel. Her Majesty's ship Vestal has sent her boats to prevent the approach of dhows to the Umpesi, while the Portuguese troops have been engaged in checking the land transport.", 'last_edit_date': '1880-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1880#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.588, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We should say, rather, this is "the answer" to the question propounded; for it is not to be doubted that vigorous conjoint action on the part of the European Powers, signatories to the Treaty of Vienna and the subsequent Convention of Verona, would years ago have brought the slave trade, if not to an absolute end, at least to a minimum, and with it slavery. Surely it will not be seriously objected that diplomacy has no weapons against the recalcitrant Powers specified? We, at any rate, cannot admit so preposterous a notion, but they will be employed only when the British public has spoken out and demanded the fulfillment of treaties at the hands of the Governments which are anxious to secure, and are ever soliciting, British sympathy. Mr. Cooper says: "What is required is that the laws shall no longer recognize human beings as property, and that the buying and selling of them shall be made felony. It is this recognition by the law of property in man which lies at the root of the whole mischief."

Our limited space precludes a more extended review of this timely work, which is elegantly got up, and has a map containing the latest discoveries in Africa. We strongly recommend it to our readers, whose attention we call to the following extract from the preface, which is at once a prophecy and a warning: "Either slavery will be abolished in the Mohammedan countries, and with it the slave trade in Africa, or the world must witness a new slave-market of enormous extent.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.597, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The accusation is a solemn one. "The Sultan," M. Rohlfs informs us, "is a wholesale merchant himself. What is that in which he deals? What is it? Why, his brother man; he procures such for his own benefit by razzias over the surrounding peoples, or over his own subjects, so long as these latter have not embraced Islamism." In order to understand the abominations connected with the Eastern slave trade, we must rid ourselves of our European ideas, and enter a new world, in which men and events have in store for us more than one subject of surprise.

It is easy to form an opinion as to the importance of this slave traffic in this region, when we know the extent of the caravans that convey the negroes from Kouka. During many weeks, the preparations and the departure fill the capital with noise and bustle. Long files of camels are laden with provisions, two thousand armed men serve as an escort, and the human flock altogether counts four thousand heads. For the Sultan, for his horsemen, for his wholesale merchants, for the entire city, the caravan season is a great annual festivity; for the slave, it is the moment of banishment, the renewal of sufferings, and perhaps the eve of his death. Very speedily all this multitude has taken a northern direction, and soon it disappears from the side of the desert.

But this crowd of unhappy beings, these miserable creatures of all ages—children, young men, old men and women—where are they going? What agricultural or industrial labour demands them from the Eastern coast? What route will they take, since the north of Africa, the borders of the Mediterranean, belong to those Powers which proscribe the traffic? It is on account of these apparent difficulties, and because of the mysteries in which the Oriental trade has been involved, that it has been able to conceal itself, until the present day, from the observation of Europe.

We refrain, for the moment, from replying to the first of these inquiries. We shall learn later what becomes of these unfortunates.

We are about to see how these flocks of men, in spite of their number, can, without hindrance or denouncement, cross those countries in which the slave trade is prohibited.

Between Tripoli and Kouka lies the Oasis of the Fezzan, in which the Porte holds a garrison of five hundred men, commanded by a Kobrassi.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.622, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SLAVERY IN CENTRAL AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 19, a paper on "Slavery in its relation to Trade in Tropical Africa" was read before the Society of Arts, by Commander V. L. Cameron, R.N., C.B. The Earl of Dundonald was in the chair.

Commander Lovett Cameron, in the course of his opening remarks, said the slave trade went on all round the continent of Africa, and commerce had gone on with it. Our trade with the West Coast of Africa had gone on since the time of the Tudors. For centuries that trade was in slaves, and its increase was slow; but after several blows had been struck at that trade—among others by the liberation of slaves in the West Indian Islands, in America, and in Cuba—instead of their being any injury done to our commerce, our trade with the West Coast of Africa increased by leaps and bounds. It was only in 1850 or shortly after that we attacked a great nest of slave dealers in Lagos, and in 1861 it was made a British colony. Up to that time there had been no trade there except in slaves; but last year the trade of Lagos amounted to £357,831 imports, and £538,980 exports. And yet only thirty-eight years ago that place was of absolutely no value to us for legitimate commerce. On the Gold Coast slavery had been practically abolished by the British Government, but yet there was a good deal still existing owing to the native customs of the people. Even if the export of slaves from Africa was prevented entirely, the internal trade in them would still be enormous.

Formerly the slave trade was subsidiary to the ivory trade, but when porters were no longer wanted for the latter, the former remained, only the men were killed and the women and children carried away. It had been said that domestic slavery must be allowed, and that was a very difficult question to settle. In his opinion, we should, as in India, abolish the legal status of slavery, but should not rout out all the households where no complaint was made. As long as domestic slavery existed there would be a market for slaves. We must have nothing to do with slavery; while the slave trade continued it was impossible for legitimate commerce to go on as it should! If the slave trade were done away with, they would find that all other trade would flourish.

In answer to questions Commander Lovett Cameron said he had avoided speaking of the Germans for diplomatic reasons.

He had a plan for the total abolition of slavery in Africa, which he hoped to explain shortly. It was, in brief, to establish a barricade across the country by the way of the lakes, and to get authority to maintain order on that line.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, on February 26, presided over a large meeting, held in Exeter Hall, when two African explorers, Commander Cameron and Captain Hore, were announced to speak.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.607, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Extensive Slave Trade Practices in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Having waited with much impatience in the hope that some one of your many friends here would, through the medium of the African Times and your own instrumentality, expose some grave evils which our authorities overlook, and which are consequently increasing more and more; and, being disappointed, I humbly beg to be excused in asking your indulgence and wonted perseverance whilst I make this attempt at an exposure of one of them. Since 1872, a year which has been proverbial for all but what is good and prosperous for this Settlement as well as for its inhabitants, the demon of slavery, which it was thought at and after the cession had received its death-blow, has been gradually recovering, and is now, I am sorry to say, in almost its wonted strength, but very much disguised; to wit—prior to the year in question, although the interior countries were one amphitheatre of war, yet the captives taken at the wars hardly found their way here except as fugitives from their masters; but now the case is altered—instead of legitimate produce being brought to the Ejinrin and the Tkorodu markets, and instead of the Lagos', 'last_edit_date': '1876-08-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1876#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.588, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'And now Portugal must—must put an end to the slave-trade from her East African possessions—or if she is unable to do so must be constrained to withdraw from the scene and allow some one else to do it for her. The horrible slave-trade carried on by the Arabs up the Persian Gulf, from the East Coasts of Africa, must be swept away. Let due notice be given in those regions, that after a certain date all slave-trade will be treated as piracy, and then a few examples will close the infamous slave-trade history of the Arab dhows.

Yes, the dawn of the day of civilization, of Christian civilization, is deepening on the African horizon.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.601, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.609, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN FOREIGN SLAVE-TRADE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A Blue-book lately issued by the Foreign Office furnishes undeniable proof that an enormous traffic in slaves is still carried on, and this within the ostensible range of British influence. It is not, however, in West African waters, or from the West African Coast, that this infamous trade is carried on. On the contrary, and as we have so often pointed out, the source and centre of this great human curse exists within the dominions of that great pet of so many of our public men—and private men, too—the Sultan. It is by the Turkish Government, through its recognized agents abroad, that the inhuman traffic, in violation of all treaty law, is now persevered in. One of our brethren of the press, writing on this painful subject, says: "Throughout the Ottoman Empire slavery is a social institution; it subdues, it flogs, it strangles, it does worse, at will. Girls and boys, men and women, notwithstanding treaties, are sold in open market. And what, it may be asked, is the value of a Parliamentary statement, commonly known as a Blue-book, if it be not to interpret the true significance of facts like these? No one, of course, expects England to enter upon a new crusade against the Ottoman on behalf of his Circassian or Georgian subjects; yet, when revelations so harrowing and revolting are made in official correspondence, it appears to be time that we should refrain, once and for ever, from interference on behalf of the Ottoman barbarism, and leave 'the unspeakable' to act with independence against whatever Power may persist in regarding him as an offence and a danger." We could not state our own sentiments and feelings in better language, and we thankfully endorse every word.—_Ed. A.T._', 'last_edit_date': '1881-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1881#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.603, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: European demand and intervention were primary drivers in the development and exacerbation of the African slave trade.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that European demand and intervention were primary drivers in the development and exacerbation of the African slave trade, while also acknowledging the complex interplay of internal African factors. The textbook highlights the role of European merchants and planters in intensifying the demand for slaves, particularly in response to the resurgence of plantation systems in Brazil and Cuba, and the development of clove plantations on Zanzibar and Pemba. European traders, including those from France and Portugal, were actively involved in the slave trade, with their demand for African natural products like ivory and palm oil intertwined with the internal slave trade. The European policy of controlling the trade in firearms made external trade more important to African rulers, indirectly fueling the slave trade. However, the text also emphasizes the internal dynamics of African communities and pre-existing local and regional trade patterns, suggesting that while European demand was significant, it was not the sole driver. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight that European ships initiated the foreign slave trade on the West Coast of Africa, leading to kidnapping and the establishment of forts to facilitate the trade, and that European energy and markets stimulated the trade, which had existed for time immemorial in Africa. The articles also discuss the role of European powers in the trade's continuation despite treaty engagements to suppress it, indicating a lack of consistent effort to end the trade. Both sources acknowledge the existence of domestic slavery in Africa prior to European involvement, suggesting that while European demand intensified the trade, it did not originate it. This nuanced perspective provides a comprehensive understanding of the slave trade's development, highlighting both European influence and pre-existing African practices.

gha_sources: [{'document_title': 'The countries of the Zambezi basin', 'section_title': 'The slave trade and incorporation into the capitalist world economy', 'content': 'Unprecedented commercial penetration from the East African coast during the nineteenth century resulted in the incorporation of most of Central Africa into the capitalist world economy. As in the case of West Africa, the slave trade figured prominently in the process by which the region, especially north of the Zambezi river, became part of the periphery of the international trading system. Despite some basic similarities, there were important differences. Many of the captives were exported to the Indian Ocean plantation system, Madagascar and the Middle East rather than to the New World. There was also the very significant role of the ivory trade, and the fact that the far-reaching changes accompanying this involvement in international trade were compressed into a much shorter time-frame. Moreover, the level of violence that accompanied the slave trade was probably higher in Central Africa, creating unprecedented fragmentation and rural dislocation. While some Central African trading societies, or at least the dominant class within them, benefited in the short run through their participation in the ivory and slave trade, they ultimately became subordinate to and dependent upon the international trading system whose centres of decision-making lay outside Africa. 22 Several factors operated simultaneously to expand the slave trade during the first half of the nineteenth century. As a result of the resurgence of the plantation system in north-eastern Brazil and the subsequent development of sugar estates in Cuba, slave-traders in appreciable numbers from the West Indies and Latin America began to visit Mozambican ports where captives were generally cheaper than in West Africa and the limited British naval force far less intimidating.$^{23}$ Simultaneously, French planters on the islands of Bourbon (now called RØunion), Seychelles and the Mascarenes, as well as the rulers of Madagascar, intensified their demand for slaves. The most significant stimulant, however, was the development of clove plantations on the islands of Zanzibar and Pemba shortly after the turn of the century. 24 Conditions within Central Africa facilitated the growing demand for slave labour. Bisa, Yao and Chikunda trade networks already linked the interior to the coastal markets of Kilwa, Mozambique Island and Quelimane. [{'id': 566, 'article_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'full_section_title': 'Lord Stanley on the Motion for a Special Committee (Western Africa)', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': 'We join issue further with Lord Stanley on the question of debt and duty to Africa. He says that we owe none; we say that we owe both—that we owe them not only as Christians, but as Britons. The Christian claim his lordship coolly dismisses; he cannot, or he will not, understand or admit it. It is not, therefore, the less mighty and real; but we will pass it by, and come to the national one. Do we, as a nation, owe anything to Africa? Lord Stanley says we might have been under this delusion thirty years ago, but that we are wiser now, and not to be so gulled. The slave-trade was not created by England, or by any Europeans, he says; England found and used it, and no doubt aggravated the evil; but sixty years have passed since we made any money in that way, and therefore, whatever debt was owing to the people of Africa on this score, had certainly been by this time paid off." The statute of limitations, we presume—a creditable plea, no doubt, for a so-called Christian people! But Lord Stanley had not studied his facts. We did not _find_ in Africa that _foreign slave-trade_ which has wrought such incalculable evil in Africa. We found domestic slavery and abominations innumerable, but no foreign slave-trade. When European ships first went down the West Coast in search of slaves, they found it.

difficult to obtain any. There were none offering for sale. The shipmasters were obliged to have recourse to kidnapping—pan-yaring those who came off to their ships to trade in produce. But the Europeans got possession of points on the Coast—they built forts—they tempted with articles and goods that were greedily sought after. Slaves, slaves, slaves, was their great demand. We have no space here to trace the progress and tell the horrors of the new foreign slave-trade thus inaugurated. But, as has been already stated, we and other Europeans reduced the population of those very Gold Coast territories, now so Pharisaically complained of, from five millions to about two hundred thousand, having ourselves shipped from thence—only from that Gold Coast to one—a single one of our West India islands, Jamaica, above 950,000 slaves within a period of one hundred and ten years, in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; while millions were shipped during the same period from other parts of the doomed coast to other colonies. And this, Lord Stanley says, has been amply atoned for, if there really was anything to be atoned for, by a sixty-years' discontinuance of the infamous practice! For all efforts on our part to suppress the slave-trade, Lord Stanley treats as a work of supererogation. It has been, he says, a waste of money and of valuable lives, some one of which latter was more valuable than the whole existence of our African colonies. We have reduced that horrid slave export trade from Africa from two or three hundred thousand victims a-year to perhaps five or ten thousand (from the West Coast); but all this was not worth one of the lives expended in the work!'}, {'id': 572, 'article_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'full_section_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'last_edit_date': '02-21-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_03_1865', 'content': "

Mr. Cardwell said he alluded to the statement that the noble lord (Lord A. Churchill) had improved the occasion by addressing his missionary friends. With regard to the efforts which they had made for the suppression of the slave-trade, he did not know a brighter page in the history of this country, following truly on a darker page, than that which began with the abolition of the slave-trade which was consummated by Lord Derby's Government in 1833, by the total extinction of slavery in the British dominions, and which was now being continued in what this country was doing on the African coast. He did not agree that the slave-trade could be traced back to a period anterior to history. He rather believed it did not commence until the European era; but he did agree with the right hon. gentleman in quoting the words of the King of Dahomey, that had the white man not been to buy the slave, the trade could never have been carried to the extent it had been. Fully agreeing in the propriety, and not wishing to limit the extent of the inquiry, he regretted to hear one part of the right hon. gentleman's speech. He did not think it was necessary to refer in terms of reproach to those now holding the Government offices on the Coast. They had better go into the inquiry in a dispassionate spirit, not having previously condemned those who were to be brought before them. He much regretted the remarks that had been made with reference to Mr. Pine, the Governor of the Gold Coast. When the hon. baronet brought forward this motion last year, he disclaimed any intention of making an attack personally on the Governor. Mr. Pine had expressed his anxiety to be examined and to have the charges fully inquired into, and had obtained leave of absence for that purpose, so that the noble lord could examine him before the committee. On Mr. Pine's part, he wished to take this opportunity of explaining a matter which at this time last year he was not in a position to explain, and which had given Governor Pine much pain. There was an impression last year that the Governor went away in the Rattlesnake for the benefit of his health without making arrangements with Colonel Conran for the security of the troops. He had since been assured that the Governor had made such arrangements with Colonel Conran as were necessary for the welfare of the troops before he left the Coast. (Hear.) He would refer briefly to what he conceived to be the object of these settlements, and on this point he was glad to find that in the main he agreed with the noble lord. Certainly it was not colonisation. To that climate no man living would wish to see the Anglo-Saxon race emigrate, and colonisation was never attempted there. The purpose of the settlements was merely to be ancillary to our other efforts for the extinction of the slave-trade, and to prevent the recurrence of the horrors that had been perpetrated in that part of the world. How far the four settlements answered this purpose it would be for the committee to inquire. Whereas in 1700 the whole of the Coast was subject to the slave-trade, now it was limited by the squadron to a few places; and now one of the steamers of which they had heard was lying at one of those places ready to start, but was prevented by the vigilance of the squadron. Our policy being the object in view, it was a question whether it was desirable to have four separate governors, and whether four different settlements did not encourage four different policies; whether the expense might not be diminished by having one government, and whether four separate military forces had not to be kept up, as each governor would naturally wish to acquire the maximum force, to be prepared for any difficulty which might arise, and whether having four governors was not likely to encourage the occurrence of four difficulties at one time, whereas under one governor he would temporise and dispose of one before he got into another. For these reasons he thought there was a legitimate subject for inquiry, particularly as he found a considerable increase in the number of troops kept on the Coast, and that an increase of force did not satisfy the demand, because that demand was still increasing. He found, also, that the buildings in the colony were not sufficient for the troops, and that it would be necessary to come to the House for a vote, but he was unwilling to do so pending the inquiry which he knew would take place upon that point, and also because he knew that the force at the Gold Coast must be removed before the commencement of the next rainy season. The conclusion, therefore, which the Government came to was not to ask the House for an increased vote of money for buildings, though he would have been prepared to deal with the question but for the intended inquiry. All the surrounding circumstances of the case led him to think that there should be a committee of inquiry, and another strong reason for wishing for the assistance of a parliamentary committee was that this was not a new question, but it was one which rested upon high and great authority—viz., that of a committee on which sat Lord Derby, who was at the time Colonial Secretary; Earl Russell, who had since been Colonial Secretary; and Mr. Speaker, and many other members of influence; and it was upon their express recommendation that a governor was appointed for Sierra Leone. He said, therefore, that it would be most right to have the authority of a fresh committee and further evidence, in order that they might decide the question as to what should be done in the future. The right hon. gentleman having given notice of inquiry, he had prepared for it during the recess, and to that end he had requested General Ord, the Governor of Bermuda, who was at home upon leave, to visit the Coast of Africa, and he had done so, and had since returned; and when the committee met, the instructions which were given him and his report, which had not yet been presented, would be laid before them. General Ord believed that these settlements were important auxiliaries for the purposes for which they were instituted; that many alterations might be made for increasing the efficiency and diminishing the expenses of those establishments; and it was in accordance with his general recommendations that the Secretary at War and himself had taken the step of reducing the force employed upon the Coast. He had thus shown the views which the Government entertained as to its being safe and expedient to diminish the military force. He would enter into the inquiry with the greatest pleasure, and he sincerely trusted that the result of the inquiries would be not only increased efficiency and economy in the settlements which they might think it expedient to maintain upon the Coast of Africa, but he also earnestly trusted that the committee would go into the inquiry in the spirit which the right hon. gentleman had predicated, though not in a spirit to withdraw their noble efforts for the suppression of the slave-trade, but that those efforts should be made still more efficient for the purposes for which they were instituted, for he knew of no efforts more noble in which this country had ever engaged. Nor, looking round at what was passing in other nations, he thought that this was not the time for flinching from the task they had undertaken; but that the sense of universal detestation and determination to abolish this infamous traffic, should induce them to continue those efforts, and thus bring about a result not less glorious than that which was accomplished on the day when this country abolished slavery in our own colonies."}, {'id': 5725, 'article_title': 'THE ANTI-SLAVERY SOCIETY', 'full_section_title': 'THE ANTI-SLAVERY SOCIETY', 'last_edit_date': '07-31-1888', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1888#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1888', 'content': "Lord GRANVILLE had to apologise for the short time he would be enabled to stay at the meeting, as his presence was required in the House of Lords; but Mr. Sturge, the Chairman of the Society, clothed with the authority which his name and his labour had given him, would take his (Lord Granville's) place. He was not quite sure that the fact of a member of the Society of Friends presiding over a meeting graced by the presence of Cardinal Lavigerie, Bishops, Archbishops, and most distinguished clergy and laymen, representing different politics and religious persuasions, did not accentuate the fact that there were things on which they differed. But they all agreed that slavery and the slave trade were contrary to the laws of natural and revealed religion, and hateful in the sight of that God who watched over all of us. They had been summoned there that afternoon to hear what the Cardinal had to tell them with regard to slavery in Africa. He did not believe that his Eminence would inculcate upon them the abstract iniquity of slavery and the slave trade, for in that case he would be preaching to converts. It was true that some time ago we, by the introduction of European energy, by opening the lucrative and large markets, gave a stimulus to the slave trade which had existed for time immemorial in Africa; but, during a hundred years, we had done something to wipe off the reproach. He thought that his Eminence would speak to them of the increase of the slave trade in the centre and the East of Africa, confirming the information which we had received from our explorers, our missionaries, and from Her Majesty's Consuls. He thought and hoped he (the Cardinal) would give them his views as to the best means of combating this evil. They would agree with him in thinking that it would be absurd for Englishmen, who had got possession of the most favoured spots in the uncivilized world, that we should be jealous of any other European nation desiring to increase their opportunities of promoting civilization. Belgium, France, Germany had lately been pursuing that policy, and as a consequence we were in possession of greater rights and of greater responsibilities, and the nations he had just mentioned would feel with us the weight of that responsibility. In 1815, at the Congress at Vienna, there was a strong condemnation of the slave trade. In 1822, at a Conference at Verona, the Duke of Wellington endeavoured to have the slave trade declared piracy. At the Congress of Berlin our Plenipotentiaries found it impossible to bring forward the question at all. He was not sure that at this moment there was any obstacle to these nations coming together, and trying to arrive at the most judicious method for the purpose of putting an end to, or greatly diminishing, the horrors which he was afraid even exceeded the former Trans-oceanic traffic. The noble Earl concluded by calling upon Cardinal Lavigerie to address the meeting."}]

[{'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL COMPANIES FOR AFRICAN TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'But it takes so long to undo evil, and destroy its baneful venom among mankind, that the infamous slave-trade, though scotched, is not yet killed. European Governments, even when sincere, are lax and feeble, fitful and vacillating in their inadequate efforts against it. It can only be thoroughly destroyed in one way. It flourished in an European and Asiatic desire for an accursed gain.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Cooper—now the Nestor of the anti-slavery cause—renders an immense service to it by this, his last contribution to its literature. Apart from his extensive experience as an active worker with the earliest champions of negro emancipation, his intimate knowledge of the movement, his ceaseless vigilance, and the minute attention he has given to the latest developments of the East African slave trade entitle him to address the public with authority upon this momentous subject, and we venture to hope an adequate response may be made to his earnest appeal to the British Government to make a vigorous effort to annihilate the iniquity of slavery, as the main source of the slave trade. The writer very forcibly demonstrates that even the best-intentioned measures against the traffic in slaves must fail so long as its great provocative, slavery, exists. Sir Bartle Frere and other equally distinguished modern advocates of the abolition of the slave trade, have been driven by their own experience to advance the same view; and the chief purpose of Mr. Cooper's book is to submit—which we think he does conclusively—that, were our Government to take up the question in earnest, the task of inducing Mohammedan Powers to abolish slavery would prove less difficult than is alleged.

"The principal countries on behalf of which the present African slave trade is carried on are Turkey, Egypt, Persia, Tunis, Morocco, and Madagascar. On them the responsibility for the present state of Africa now mainly rests. The rulers of these countries have in nearly every instance, at one time or other, condemned both slavery and the slave trade, and have entered into treaty engagements for the suppression of the slave-markets throughout their dominions. How is it, then, that the slave trade is still carried on in those countries, in violation both of law and treaty engagements? One answer to this will probably be found in the fact that the European Powers, though solemnly pledged to bring the system to a definitive end, have taken little interest in the subject for the last thirty years, during which period the traffic has pretty steadily increased."', 'last_edit_date': '1875-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.65, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Mediterranean Negro Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our readers will not fail to have noticed the following paragraph immediately following our leaders in the last number of this Journal:—"THE SLAVE TRADE. Constantinople, November 9.—An English steamer arrived here on Wednesday from Malta with twenty slaves on board. The traffic in slaves between Tripoli and Constantinople, via Malta, is very brisk." Few, we believe, will have been prepared for such an announcement as this. Yet, although it appeared in all our daily papers, we have not seen any other notice taken in them of the alleged facts—any condemnation of Turkey—any censure of ourselves. We have been holding public meetings in condemnation of the East African Slave Trade, the British Government has been sending out a special envoy to Zanzibar, and is understood to be adopting efficacious measures for putting an end to the traffic from Africa to Persia and Arabia—all highly commendable, and our most obvious duty—but yet here we have the Slave Trade, the foreign African Slave Trade, carried on under our very eyes—carried on where we can intercept and destroy it forthwith, if we so choose, without any extraordinary effort on our part to do so being required,—here we have it, duly exposed as an item of news in the columns of all the London daily papers, without its having elicited any justly indignant comments, provoked any addresses to Her Majesty's Government, or even, so far as we can learn (not having been ourself present), given rise to a single remark at the Baroness Burdett Coutts' evening reunion, where a Wilberforce, the Bishop of Winchester, presided over the Anti-Slave Trade Conversazione. We should have imagined that, if any item of Slave Trade news could possibly excite attention and rouse indignation, it would be such an item as this. For what does this Mediterranean Slave Trade from Tripoli to Constantinople, in steamer via Malta, mean? Where do these poor wretches thus conveyed to their final destination, come from? Alas! they have previously formed part of one of those caravans of slaves which traverse the Great Desert, from Bornou, in Central Africa, to Tripoli, the whole route of which through that Desert is clearly marked by the bleached bones of innumerable human victims of that accursed trade, carried on in Central as in Eastern Africa by Mahomedans for the supply of Mahometan countries. We have been too long accustomed to hear that this Central African Slave Trade from Bornou to Tripoli (the intense horrors of which have been often exposed, and are again exposed in the little work by Mons. Berlioz, which we are reproducing in our columns) cannot be reached by any effort of the British Government. This assertion has been invariably denied by us. It has been well known that the final destination, the profitable market, for perhaps the greater portion of the survivors of those horrible caravans, was in Turkey; and that, in some way or other, they were constantly being conveyed to Smyrna and Constantinople. Is it not, therefore, evident that a little energy and honest determination on the part of the British Government would suffice to break this final link in the chain of the traffic; and that without any very great sacrifices being necessary to effect it? There cannot be any reasonable doubt on this point; and there being no room for any such doubt, makes us to be clearly criminal participators in all the worst barbarities and horrors of that Central African Slave Trade, which we profess so vehemently to deplore and to condemn. Why are we so? Why is this, at least, nominally Christian country thus allowed to be dragged in the year 1873 through the gory mire of that accursed trade, which insults God and outrages humanity. Why is it, but that the demon of greed has seized the heart of this people in his mighty grasp, making all its other emotions secondary to the', 'last_edit_date': '1873-01-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_01_1873#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We should say, rather, this is "the answer" to the question propounded; for it is not to be doubted that vigorous conjoint action on the part of the European Powers, signatories to the Treaty of Vienna and the subsequent Convention of Verona, would years ago have brought the slave trade, if not to an absolute end, at least to a minimum, and with it slavery. Surely it will not be seriously objected that diplomacy has no weapons against the recalcitrant Powers specified? We, at any rate, cannot admit so preposterous a notion, but they will be employed only when the British public has spoken out and demanded the fulfillment of treaties at the hands of the Governments which are anxious to secure, and are ever soliciting, British sympathy. Mr. Cooper says: "What is required is that the laws shall no longer recognize human beings as property, and that the buying and selling of them shall be made felony. It is this recognition by the law of property in man which lies at the root of the whole mischief."

Our limited space precludes a more extended review of this timely work, which is elegantly got up, and has a map containing the latest discoveries in Africa. We strongly recommend it to our readers, whose attention we call to the following extract from the preface, which is at once a prophecy and a warning: "Either slavery will be abolished in the Mohammedan countries, and with it the slave trade in Africa, or the world must witness a new slave-market of enormous extent.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East and Central Africa Foreign Slave Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The accusation is a solemn one. "The Sultan," M. Rohlfs informs us, "is a wholesale merchant himself. What is that in which he deals? What is it? Why, his brother man; he procures such for his own benefit by razzias over the surrounding peoples, or over his own subjects, so long as these latter have not embraced Islamism." In order to understand the abominations connected with the Eastern slave trade, we must rid ourselves of our European ideas, and enter a new world, in which men and events have in store for us more than one subject of surprise.

It is easy to form an opinion as to the importance of this slave traffic in this region, when we know the extent of the caravans that convey the negroes from Kouka. During many weeks, the preparations and the departure fill the capital with noise and bustle. Long files of camels are laden with provisions, two thousand armed men serve as an escort, and the human flock altogether counts four thousand heads. For the Sultan, for his horsemen, for his wholesale merchants, for the entire city, the caravan season is a great annual festivity; for the slave, it is the moment of banishment, the renewal of sufferings, and perhaps the eve of his death. Very speedily all this multitude has taken a northern direction, and soon it disappears from the side of the desert.

But this crowd of unhappy beings, these miserable creatures of all ages—children, young men, old men and women—where are they going? What agricultural or industrial labour demands them from the Eastern coast? What route will they take, since the north of Africa, the borders of the Mediterranean, belong to those Powers which proscribe the traffic? It is on account of these apparent difficulties, and because of the mysteries in which the Oriental trade has been involved, that it has been able to conceal itself, until the present day, from the observation of Europe.

We refrain, for the moment, from replying to the first of these inquiries. We shall learn later what becomes of these unfortunates.

We are about to see how these flocks of men, in spite of their number, can, without hindrance or denouncement, cross those countries in which the slave trade is prohibited.

Between Tripoli and Kouka lies the Oasis of the Fezzan, in which the Porte holds a garrison of five hundred men, commanded by a Kobrassi.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BADAGRY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The traffic in slaves is still carried on between Porto-Novo, this place, and Whydah. This inflicts very great injury on the legitimate trader, as the slave-dealers make sacrifices on the sale and purchase of goods and produce, in order to drive the English traders out of the market. Their profit on slaves compensates them largely for the loss they thus sustain in driving away the enemies of that traffic.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-02-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_02_1862#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SLAVERY IN CENTRAL AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 19, a paper on "Slavery in its relation to Trade in Tropical Africa" was read before the Society of Arts, by Commander V. L. Cameron, R.N., C.B. The Earl of Dundonald was in the chair.

Commander Lovett Cameron, in the course of his opening remarks, said the slave trade went on all round the continent of Africa, and commerce had gone on with it. Our trade with the West Coast of Africa had gone on since the time of the Tudors. For centuries that trade was in slaves, and its increase was slow; but after several blows had been struck at that trade—among others by the liberation of slaves in the West Indian Islands, in America, and in Cuba—instead of their being any injury done to our commerce, our trade with the West Coast of Africa increased by leaps and bounds. It was only in 1850 or shortly after that we attacked a great nest of slave dealers in Lagos, and in 1861 it was made a British colony. Up to that time there had been no trade there except in slaves; but last year the trade of Lagos amounted to £357,831 imports, and £538,980 exports. And yet only thirty-eight years ago that place was of absolutely no value to us for legitimate commerce. On the Gold Coast slavery had been practically abolished by the British Government, but yet there was a good deal still existing owing to the native customs of the people. Even if the export of slaves from Africa was prevented entirely, the internal trade in them would still be enormous.

Formerly the slave trade was subsidiary to the ivory trade, but when porters were no longer wanted for the latter, the former remained, only the men were killed and the women and children carried away. It had been said that domestic slavery must be allowed, and that was a very difficult question to settle. In his opinion, we should, as in India, abolish the legal status of slavery, but should not rout out all the households where no complaint was made. As long as domestic slavery existed there would be a market for slaves. We must have nothing to do with slavery; while the slave trade continued it was impossible for legitimate commerce to go on as it should! If the slave trade were done away with, they would find that all other trade would flourish.

In answer to questions Commander Lovett Cameron said he had avoided speaking of the Germans for diplomatic reasons.

He had a plan for the total abolition of slavery in Africa, which he hoped to explain shortly. It was, in brief, to establish a barricade across the country by the way of the lakes, and to get authority to maintain order on that line.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, on February 26, presided over a large meeting, held in Exeter Hall, when two African explorers, Commander Cameron and Captain Hore, were announced to speak.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'And now Portugal must—must put an end to the slave-trade from her East African possessions—or if she is unable to do so must be constrained to withdraw from the scene and allow some one else to do it for her. The horrible slave-trade carried on by the Arabs up the Persian Gulf, from the East Coasts of Africa, must be swept away. Let due notice be given in those regions, that after a certain date all slave-trade will be treated as piracy, and then a few examples will close the infamous slave-trade history of the Arab dhows.

Yes, the dawn of the day of civilization, of Christian civilization, is deepening on the African horizon.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'PARLIAMENTARY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Lord STRATHEDEN (the consistent enemy of the abominable slave trade in East Africa) moved an address to Her Majesty, praying that such measures as were necessary to assist the cruisers employed in the repression of the slave trade on the eastern coast of Africa might be adopted.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1872#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Slave Trade in Africa in 1872', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Iniquitous commerce and the residence of the contractors. It is there that the large societies of the traffickers are organized. There they find bankers who lend them money at an interest as high as cent. per cent.; the dockyards of the city prepare for them fleets of vessels to re-ascend the valley of the Nile; the neighbouring populations, accustomed to live by plunder, furnish them with horsemen and foot soldiers; some master scoundrel is placed at the head of these bands; they collect provisions for a year or more. When all is in readiness, on a fine day, the wind blowing from the North, the whole expedition suddenly disappears in a southern direction. No one can tell what is about to be done. Should any more inquisitive traveller wish to know what will become of these men; let him beware. They would begin by alarming him as to the difficulties of the voyage—the morasses, fevers, ferocious animals, and negroes still more terrible. If he persist in his inquiries, they give him to understand that there is connected with these solitudes some frightful mystery which he must not know, and that death awaits the individual who is bold enough to despise counsel. They say in explanation of the expedition that the armed men are appointed to hunt elephants, and to protect the enterprise against the attacks of the enterprising trader. These latter, not contented with the exchange of their small articles of merchandise for ivory, desire to obtain the monopoly of so lucrative a commerce for themselves. Indeed, every year large cargoes of ivory are sent to Khartoum. Slaves have not appeared there since Turkey prohibited the importation of the negroes fifteen years ago. Secret correspondents come to conduct them beyond the city by the desert to their destination, of which, of course, they know nothing. It is by these means, that the enormities of the slave trade have been concealed, as with an impenetrable veil.

The following circumstance, however, furnishes some important information on the subject:—

The death of a Frenchman was one day announced, who had been at the head of a considerable establishment, and was everywhere known as a merchant in horses, and in elephants' teeth; he wished in life to be regarded as a gentleman.

He had, by dint of labour, reached the high position of his ancestors; but what did his books, which had been kept with scrupulous exactness, disclose?

hh: The transatlantic slave trade and European imperialism have profoundly shaped Africa's historical trajectory, political and social landscapes, and current global position.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively provide substantial evidence supporting the claim that the transatlantic slave trade and European imperialism have profoundly shaped Africa's historical trajectory, political and social landscapes, and current global position. The textbook highlights the significant political impact of foreign rule, noting the loss of sovereignty of African states and the imposition of fixed colonial boundaries that disrupted traditional political and economic zones. It emphasizes Africa's incorporation into the capitalist world-economy, driven partly by the slave trade, and the cultural devastation caused by the slave trade and colonialism, including the suppression of African cultural values and the imposition of foreign control. The racial discrimination and social humiliation faced by Africans under colonial rule contributed to a sense of inferiority and influenced the educated elite's push for independence. Economic transformations, such as the increased use of slave labor and the rise of new bureaucratic groups linked to the colonial economy, are also noted. Similarly, The African Times articles discuss the devastating effects of the slave trade on African societies and the challenges in eradicating it, despite European efforts. They highlight the role of European powers in partitioning Africa, with countries like France, Germany, and England establishing control over African territories, significantly altering the continent's political landscape. The articles mention the economic motivations behind European colonization, such as exploiting Africa's natural resources and establishing trade routes, and reflect on the cultural and social implications of European imperialism, including the imposition of foreign governance and the disruption of traditional African societies. However, they also suggest that European involvement brought some infrastructural and economic developments, albeit primarily serving colonial interests. Together, these sources illustrate the profound and multifaceted impact of the transatlantic slave trade and European imperialism on Africa, leaving indelible marks on its political, social, and economic landscapes, shaping its historical trajectory, and influencing its current global position.

JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. Lucas's "Historical Geography of the British Colonies" (Frowde).

In discussing the influences which have combined to render possible that fairly precise delimitation of frontiers in West Africa which any ordinary map of the continent now displays, Mr. Lucas points out that nations take to colonial enterprise for the most opposite reasons—sometimes in consequence of a great failure, sometimes in consequence of a great success. For the Germans the result of the war of 1870 was to consolidate the German nation, and when it ended they wanted new openings. These they found outside Europe—in the Pacific and in Africa. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "COMING" CONTINENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In an article, entitled "Africa for Africans," published in a magazine issued in Washington, U.S.A., the vast possibilities of progress and development possessed by this continent are so eloquently and aptly set forth that we quote the passage *in extenso*:

The German Reichstag has increased its annual appropriation for the exploration of Africa. Italy has despatched a party to Abyssinia for geographical and mercantile purposes. She has also concluded treaties which promise to make Assab a centre of commerce. The Sultan of Morocco has authorized Spain to take possession of Santa Cruz del Mar, and the Sultan of Zanzibar has purchased six superior steamers to constitute a regular coast service, in the interest of commerce and for the suppression of the slave-trade. The International African Association, which owes its origin to the philanthropic initiative of Leopold II., King of the Belgians, has received large subscriptions and pushed forward exploring expeditions to start and equip the line of hospitable and scientific stations which are to bound the East and West Coast, and form a civilizing girdle around Central Africa. And the results following the explorations of Livingstone and Stanley and De Brazza are attracting the attention of the civilized world. What was a 'Dark Continent,' by the indomitable energy of these explorers, seems likely to prove the richest quarter of the globe. Not only does the land produce, with slight persuasion of tillage, admirable crops of cotton and coffee, but the soil is rich in diamonds on its southern coast, and in iron on its northern. Captain Burton has asserted that he knows nothing to equal the prodigious wealth of the land, even in California, or in the Brazils. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo.
